column52: Mapping exercise (with short notice of the object to be mapped) went smoothly, perhaps due to previous experience in this from calls.

column54: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1uItTusyxYXs2MPDarHuQWAEwhv0bfiCQnMRbN5V63lE/edit
column55: Complex object suggestion of performance, one for further along

column57: Thanasis - AHRC is funding PhD based at National Archives around Linked Data
column58: Linked Conservation Data
column59: Condition Checking
column60: Record when object last checked, why it was checked, condition. As freetext not structured. Also condition types.
column61: Rob - Model already has event in Provenance that could be expanded to cover condition events. Baseline version would be Encounter, could be used for inventory taking or condition report
column62: George - Using Encounter possible but should Conservation Event be in their own wrapper.
column63: Rob - Encounter fairly broad - “This actor was in this location at this point in time”
column64: Joe - Would need to add to that is it deliberate (purpose of encounter) and physical interaction (type of encounter).
column65: Thanasis - Would need to be activity as intention is part of the condition check
column66: George - Scope note mentions intentionality
column67: Thanasis - That’s not quite same as condition checking.
column68: George - Observation class might be an alternative
column69: Kevin - Confusion of meaning of condition checking
column70: Joe - Condition checking covers a variety of possibilities and degrees to the extent of the condition check
column71: Rob - Lots of nuance to condition checking.
column72: Kevin - Assessment versus comparison to existing condition record
column73: Joe - Depends, can be to confirm existing damage hasn’t changed, or to identify new damage. Some place require condition checking in isolation and then comparison afterwards (to last assessment)
column74: Thanasis - Should be part of the object model
column75: Rob - Not sure if should be directly in object, part of conservation activity wrapper. Otherwise the object record gets too large over time.
column76: Rob - Could be top level type. Seems tied to provenance, as often related to moves, but not always.
column77: Kevin - Would just need to document people get Provenance and Condition separately
column78: George - Registrars need to know where object is. If we have one wrapper for Provenance and another one for Conservation, harder to get the comprehensive picture (would need to merge the data)
column79: Thanasis - Conservation records would not include move of object around the institution
column80: Joe - Agree, that type of movement not part of conservation, but also not sure if it’s part of provenance either. If an object is moved after 150 years in one place, which results in some fundamental change. That movement is not provenance or conservation, more administrative. Movement could be driven by multiple purposes.
column81: Kevin - All the data is there, would just need to be combined by someone using the API
column82: Joe - Useful to clarify to users of the API that linkage can be made between different part of the model
column84: Joe - How do we model time. The present state of knowledge (Condition) becomes historical knowledge (Provenance)
column85: Rob - Phases an option but have avoided so far. Wikidata has tried to solve this through structured properties.
column86: Joe - Trickier in Linked Art API. A Condition event over time becomes a Provenance Event.
column87: Kevin - Need to document that all movement events need to be assembled together
column88: Joe - Can the same event be provided by two APIs at the same time.
column89: Environmental Requirements & Hazardous materials
column90: Would need text setting out optimal conditions that object should be kept in and text setting out hazardous materials and treatment
column91: Joe - Tricky. If you want to setup an exhibition on a group of objects, the data in structured form would be most useful to see the range of environmental conditions needed for an exhibition as a whole. For example if one object has much lower lighting conditions required than others, it has series of consequences for exhibition planning.
column92: Thanasis - Agree but requires further work to model this. Trying to describe this would require Event Templates from CRM
column93: Kevin - Should some of these things be more prominent e.g. hazardous materials
column94: George - Could take a incremental approach, start with freetext description fields but plan later on to add structured fields.
column95: Joe - Plans afoot to improve these things in collections management systems. Wanting to avoid setting a limited form of this in stone in the data model preventing us from expanding it in the future.
column96: Homework
column97: For next call ???
column98: Thanasis to create issues for the individual items and attempt to progress with fleshing solutions for easier decision in a following meeting.

column55: Kevin: LA sessions: Some are panels some are workshops.
column56: Rob: On the Monday there is CRM workshop, 2 hours to use as needed. Kevin: possibly longer mapping with something new versus something confident we have the answer.
column57: Rob: Monday, 6.30-7.30 intro. 7.30-8.30 known answer. Kevin: There are clashes with Thursday sessions.
column58: Bring in Michael from VGWW for the intro? They are using LA and are public so is it a good idea to bring in? Kevin: Also, people have papers being given they should be included in the intro.
column59: Chris: project lead of Van Gogh World Wide could tell something about the Linked Art implementation: Ivo Zandhuis (https://ivozandhuis.nl)
column60: Kevin: Conference is open and free but people need to register. And will switch Wednesday call to the conference technology. Worth it to run through mapping technology for the conference call?
column61: Rob: For Monday session (done before) straightforward, tombstone with expanding to provenance. Don’t want to scare off at first session. So Signet ring or Rijksmuseum object. Replay the mapping of the Stieglitz photograph. Edward is ok with that.
column62: Emmanuelle: Question if Wednesday is still open? More data modelling on Wed? Kevin: Same time as Wed call. Emmanuelle, risk of proceeding as too technical for people exposed to LA for first time. Modelling on the fly is very powerful. Demystifies the work.
column63: Kevin: Can consider the Wed call at the mapping call or email offline. Rob some agenda is good. Intros may take time. Emmanuelle: we have four sessions so they could be time. As for Thursday, formal paper presentation. Any more thoughts? Kevin: B/c only an hour maybe slightly less presentation driven? Emmanuelle: CIDOC attracts early career practitioners. There is a paper that will be published by conference organizers. Kevin: Have a look via email about V&A presentations and DH presentations that did not happen. Can be adapted. Emmanuelle will get back to organizers about the details for each session.
column64: Issue 311 Image rights
column65: Dave: Common statements that can be used across collections. Rob: and types of objects.
column66: Rob: Text we have covered. Structured data form (We may not need).
column67: In diagram CCBi. Usage rights not generic, has to be specific. Rights “E30” do not have many properties. Some attempt to move forward. Could refer to statement just as text (does not refer to the object). Antoine: (statements not linguistic object). Rightsstatements.org, two patterns. Standard statement eg CCBi. Oddity of having a type link between a specific and a more general. Use W3C recommendation but semantics are different. Statements could be standard CC statement or more complicated. Felt that it was a departure from current rights statement procedure.
column68: Rob: Is CRM pattern under a rights statement. Antoine: 99% will look different and be more complex. Exploited loophole b/c rights statements are generic things. Standardized like CCBI or statements “no copyright, no date”. Could be more than two levels. Super statement from complex statements. Talking about digital images with complex copyright and IP, hard to model but need to keep door open.
column69: Rob: Extra complexity for blank node in rights data. Not incorrect just obnoxious. Antoine, may not be incorrect, just a statement.
column70: Rob: What about treating it as a standardized statement (more obnoxious?). Antoine: Depends on use cases, strange to consider “no copyright, no commercial” as a linguistic object. Rob: Should be the page not the concept.
column71: Rob: If consider CCBi, with text following. Not ideal but best we can do? Dave: Linguistic object or URI? Rob: Image is subject to E30 right, and right is classified by license. No text to display. Dave: That would work for aggregation, but in the case of one with a tighter rights control would need a way to provide actual text of the restrictions. Eg internal use (Exhibition objects, and need to contact a specific person for publication). There may be details to convey for the full idea.
column72: Antoine: Good example for CRM pattern. Extra nodes to convey. More complex pattern may work. COuld be a landing page or SKOS node. Would a linguistic object or document. May give us a unified pattern for complex statements or statements with textual nodes.
column73: Rob: This is a reason for going the more complex route. Get this option.
column74: Antoine: Should we keep the simplest pattern for the simple cases? Dave: Other cases showing both cases to unify data and the querying behind it. Antoine: Could come up with something consistent with the two patterns. Rob: Simplest consistent pattern is goal.
column75: Issue 256
column76: Confidence statements. Probably, possible flags.

column50: Notes:
column51: Community announcements:
column52: CRM-SIG virtual meeting this week: Rob, George and Thanasis are all attending the sessions they can. Yesterday, dates were discussed, re: inclusion/exclusion of end date from `end_of_the_end`. So the year 1970 now spans from midnight 1970-01-01 to 1970-12-31T23:59.999. This breaks the current implementation.
column53: Joe: Just for info: 1970-12-31 is converted to Thursday, 31 December 1970 00:00:00 GMT+01:00
column54: George: this was indeed the consensus after much discussion
column55: Edward: is there a recommended unit of accuracy for decrementing the end?
column56: Rob: yes, with the units you are currently handling
column57: Joe: if people can/cannot use time, then software will have to resolve to seconds as default -- so what is the behaviour for midnight?
column58: Rob: this will mean that the algorithm is going to be more difficult to implement. But that we should not fight the issue.
column59: George: will collect minutes from the meeting.
column60: Community
column61: Next call (modelling) is scheduled for November 4th, probably coinciding with the US election count reveal.
column62: Rob: should we reschedule or cancel?
column63: Thanasis: well Linked Art is not US-only!
column64: Bree: a distraction would be welcome.
column65: Rob: let’s continue with it.
column66: Richard: also - UK bonfire night!
column67: Rob: The SIG is also meeting on Thursday and Friday (George is partially responsible for the agenda). Is it possible for anyone to join?
column68: George: I don’t think it’s necessary to register. It’s not a closed group. Just let me know by email.
column69: Modelling
column70: Issue 364
column71: Rob: this concerns buyers and sellers both having agents in a provenance event. For example: current owner employs someone to go to the auction house and sell something on his behalf; the seller employs someone to go to the auction house and buy the item. The net result is simply that the item transfers ownership between buyer and seller.
column72: Rob: the Getty does have considerable information relating to this. Does anyone else?
column73: Emmanuelle: certainly the YCBA doesn’t, officially. The reason is that it’s really hard to know when agents acted in official roles. Which is not well documented for obvious reasons. It’s rare to come by source data for that type of scenario. As I hear from my curators.
column74: John: it’s hard to have the definite proof. Assumptions can be made from auction catalogues. You can see the sale in a catalogue and then perceive that the item shows up in someone’s collection and then infer the relationship between the owner and the (agent) buyer.
column75: Joe: do we need a specific pattern for this? What about a nest aspect?
column76: Rob: provenance activities are already partitioned into different components. If we wanted to express this degree of precision, I think the model might work, however it might be very gnarly. It may not be worth documenting this level of complexity.
column77: Joe: a straight chain might mean that most software loses the data along the way.
column78: Rob: X object is transferred from B to A. This is already a gross simplification of what is happening. We could easily partition this up if we had greater granularity of activities, but this is not how it’s done in CRM.
column79: George: we should raise this conversation with the SIG. Changing the range of acquisition from physical-thing to a right would be a breaking change (and a big problem). But that doesn’t mean that the early modelling choice was the best one; and does not preclude the invention of a (or more) superclass to handle data which is being created/surfaced by groups like Linked Art.
column80: Rob: flag as Raise to SIG? Put it on the docket for a future (not this week’s) agenda? For now leave as out-of-scope.
column81: George: seems sensible.
column82: Joe: +1. Is there a way to cheat? I have a relationship here, which is more fully described in this long chain. You have the short sale A-B, satisfying the simple use case. But then nest all the complex in-between transfers A-C-D-E-F-B, etc. Therefore someone with the data can start modelling before SIG resolves pattern.
column83: John: One Frick example sourced from the cat raisonne: https://arcade.nyarc.org/record=b1604647~S7
column84: One more that we are sourcing from the auction catalog. https://arcade.nyarc.org/record=b1576701~S7
column85: Rob: re: John’s point, it’s hard to get to actual evidence for these events. We can model them, we don’t need additional ontology or docs. But we don’t know for sure that A1 was acting on behalf of A.
column86: Rob: raise Rights Transfer issue to the SIG. The issue of being uncertain about the activities being performed is just a lack of knowledge about the agents (potentially) involved that we can’t deal with.
column87: Issue 366
column88: Rob: adding to and removing things from collections. This comes up in Exhibitions, as Dave notes. The Set of objects that is the collection (auction lot, or set managed by institution, or set in exhibition). If we want to track the activities causing objects to be added or subtracted from these collections, then we need somewhere to manage that activity. Three possibles:
column89: On the object (all add and removes are on the object)
column90: In the collection
column91: Separate (a new top level activity which is only the manipulation of things into sets; potentially could be a Provenance activity)
column92: Joe: how does this relate to the general concept of Groups?
column93: Rob: I think it’s exactly that. If Rob joined Yale on September 21st. Is that part of Rob or part of Yale? If it’s part of Yale, there’s going to be a lot of those. But if it’s part of Rob, it will include all the various groups he has joined.
column94: Jonathan: seems to me that this should be at the Group level. We can presume the join/exit dates from the exhibition. We only need to record the exceptions.
column95: Rob: (channelling Dave) if the connection is on the object and the object is not managed by the institution that is putting on the exhibition then we would not be able to create the link in the context of the exhibition. If I wanted to make Rob’s favourite objects from around the world…
column96: [Edward lost connection for two minutes]
column97: Emmanuelle: you will not find any not-fully-accessioned objects on the YCBA website. We do not record presence of long-term loans.
column98: Joe: we do have long term loans. We have information about exhibitions which have come to us. We have paintings in Japan, so we don’t necessarily have control of the list of objects our paintings have joined.
column99: Richard: we do sometimes put loan objects online but not exhibition loans. When we are loaning to another institution, we do say that it is on loan and where.
column100: Rob: for Exhibitions, this seems like the membership / participation of an object in an exhibition is subtly different to the addition of an object to the Set. Saying that the object was in an Exhibition seems like a useful thing to be able to say. But it seems presumptuous to say that there was an activity adding my object to an exhibiting curator’s Set that they made a choice to do this. The distinction: great if objects can record their provenance, including participation in exhibitions. But if there’s a reason to be more specific about an activity that added an object into a set, then it’s the Collection’s responsibility for recording that.
column101: Joe: if you were using this data and queried a graph for an object, what data would you want back when you fetch its provenance? First question: where do we record this data. Second: where do we present it? How does the user get to that? How is it expressed?
column102: Rob: would be useful to have these links from the objects to the exhibitions but not necessarily the activity by which they were added.
column103: Richard: trying to split in my mind the difference between workflow (movement of objects) and provenance. The fact an object was in an exhibition was true. But because it replaced another one because it is light-sensitive is also true.
column104: Jonathan: yes, lots of researchers are interested in this. Especially if a work was removed early. Agree that the provenance event is: the work was in the show.
column105: Joe: where would you record the fact that four of the objects in the exhibition need to be covered on Thursdays? Intermediate events that haven’t involved the moving of the object.
column106: Jonathan: do not believe that this is data that we store in the system. Conservation does manage this type of thing, but we do not make collections system data like this available.
column107: Joe: is this linked conservation data?
column108: Thanasis: two things: One: the plan that you need to cover the thing every week. Then you have the record of whether the thing has been covered. Have not yet dealt in detail with this in Linked Conservation Data but we should do soon.
column109: Joe: total light (rather than lux level) allowances are starting to be recorded. So data is going to exist. But can we model a more generic level?
column110: Thanasis: Activity Plans will definitely cover that sort of thing. This is a different question to whether an object was part of a Set.
column111: Rob: Richard captured it well distinguishing between workflow and provenance. These things are tied together but distinct. If we need to document the action that adds/removes an object from a Set then it goes on the Set. Otherwise, responsible by the object.
column112: Issue 362
column113: Rob: in order to render a web page, it would be useful to have a Linked Art based summary of an entity that doesn’t have all of the information but a subset instead. This then would be a separate API interaction, rather than about all of the knowledge. Use cases are around result sets and summaries. Showing a quick card of the object rather than a multi-page thing. Plus ones from Dave and Ethan. This is also related to search. Having the set of fields which could be exposed for the minimum representation of the object would be useful.
column114: Joe: wondering if you want to think of Templates here. This is a use case of pulling back a painting/image/whatever else. Request all of the data, but push it through a template or filter. This allows generic implementations rather than many unique API endpoints.
column115: Rob: API design-wise, having alternate representations of resources is something that lots of info systems have: formats, subsets. Can be client or server side and there are good examples of both. Impossible to get this right for every particular case. Imagine that we will need to iterate on the approach, but if there’s a useful set of properties, we might be able to say-- here is something that doesn’t require publishers to do an awful lot.
column116: Richard: we are building the new API for our collection site. We’ve ended up with doing a subset of results to power the results and then the full record on an object page.
column117: Joe: what are you querying?
column118: Richard: Elastic
column119: Joe: certain aspects, however small, might be distant along long chains of graphs. Risks over-providing data.
column120: Rob: Search. Is there a use case that doesn’t revolve around search.
column121: Chris: there are different experiences you want to offer. So for an app or a website, it’s not only search.
column122: Joe: are these just hard-wired into the app?
column123: Chris: for example, we also do rewrites. We have to customise JSON APIs to feed different interfaces currently, rather than (currently) recomposing a single knowledge graph below it.
column124: Rob: for every institution to publish all of the possible subsets, it’s not going to be doable. But if there is one subset, then great.
column126: If you have a use case for a subset of information. Please list the fields or properties you do actually want, and list them in issue 362.

column46: George: CRM Sig meeting week of 19-23, for those interested joining live it is accessible virtually. Welcome to do a presentation if you are doing work on Linked Art or semantics.
column47: Also, Linked Art community, as part of its work has always documented itself. George has been working on systems to create more analytic documentation to note the patterns that we are producing and give them identifiers and names. Can we slice down to the “building blocks” that are declared good by the community. Creating a data infrastructure for this and sorting the information. Also working on another document that has this level of granularity. Once it becomes more solid, can be presented here and discuss if this is a good path and strategies for naming the patterns. Documentation on site has dual levels, generic and models. This would take it down one more level, so one could use pieces to construct models according to Linked Art verified/approved patterns. It could support efforts from people coming at different angles or different software.
column48: Rob: Not to replace existing documentation with automatically generated documentations. But to extend and have more a specification approach. More use case and model driven. Gives an interesting tool to see how we already use the construction. Can determine extent of future changes.
column49: Richard: Collections Trust UK link added to chat.
column50: Rob: There is a good presentation about decolonizing the database.
column51: Cultural Sensitivity Fieldshttps://github.com/linked-art/linked.art/issues/355 Question: How to model the flag as data, rather than a statement?
column52: Introduced by Richard.
column53: Question for Linked Art: How should the URI be modeled? Statement would be straightforward. Is “Culturally Sensitive” a classification of the object? Or something else.
column54: Kevin: Raising licensing quality should be avoided? And how much is related to the object and how much to the labelling?
column55: Richard: Mostly used now for Outdated terminology. If repeated in then flagged again. Images can be flagged separately if the image is sensitive but the object is not.
column56: Chris: Objects themselves could be sensitive and could be tagged. Richard: Work on that will likely start up after return of curators.
column57: Rob: Yale is beginning to look a bias and racism so this could be important.
column58: Kevin: This is a large field, so beginning activities included in the proposal. Talking with V&A about possible collaborative project. Pitt-Rivers has a labelling project.
column59: The act of flagging is important, not the note at the end of it. Discerning between the flags may be too much work.
column60: George: This seems to be part of CRM phases? These are classifications from the stand point of now. And values can change. Almost certainly need an event, if not a phase, for the assigning of value.
column61: Rob: So attribute assignment on the object. Assigns “sacred” as a type to the object?
column62: George: Yes, social status. It is a function.
column63: See Antoine’s chat comment: yes what I’ve heard about these issues (rightsstatements.org wants to work on this) is about access so enabling what Yer says, independently from a specific UI implementation.
column64: @Rob in principle all (most?) of TK is about the digital material and access to it. Though I guess it could also apply to the original material (in a physical exhibition space for example)
column65: Rob: Could be applied to digital or physical if needed.
column66: Antoine: Choose to focus on digital because of access. May reflect on original but not always the case. Flag indirectly refers back to the object. So good to keep the option open.
column67: Rob: Limited number of URI’s (18). Should implementation recognize this URI’s or do we need a metatype “cultural sensitivity flag”.
column68: Anotine: Use TK as first example. Richard: TK dealing with particular set of circumstances not solving all problems.
column69: Rob: So then we would want a metatype on the flag. Or on the attribute assignment?. More consistent would be the metatype.
column70: Kevin: Capturing the event of the flag occurring is crucial and should be in the data.
column71: Rob: Should it be separate from the object it is assigned to? Is it it’s own model that can be applied across institutions?
column72: Kevin: Need to capture that the choice was made, who undertook the act.
column73: Rob: Think we get that from attributed assignment: carried out by, timespans etc. Dimensions as a comparison (who did the measuring).
column74: Justified this as an attribute assignment.
column75: George: This is a pattern we would want to document as in theory applicable to any part of the model? Rob: Visual and textual can definitely be problematic.
column76: George: As a general pattern, should it apply across the model?
column77: Rob: Can a person be culturally sensitive. George: A group, yes. A person could be sensitive.
column78: Chris: Question of stereotype on person?
column79: George: Example from Canada. 1st PM MacDonald terrible policies with indigenous peoples so now a culturally sensitive person.
column80: Rob: Places can be sensitive. Provenance can be sensitive.
column81: Name of object inscribed on parthttps://github.com/linked-art/linked.art/issues/359 Just duplicate information?
column82: Edward: Did exercise thinking about the attribute assignment about the writing of the title on the back.
column83: Rob: SOmeone would have done some exercise in naming or labelling.
column84: Edward: Do we have to know the act in order to model the attribute assignment.
column85: Yer: Title type as inscribed so this is part.
column86: Rob: In Getty there is classification of the name if it is on the object.
column87: Where the name of the object is important. We do not want to refer to the name outside of the object record. This is nice if the part is separate from the whole. The name is carried by the part of the object. Could apply to other things, eg signature. Least change to what we have now. Add property to “names”.
column88: George: Eloquent. Possible b/c E44 and E31.
column89: Emmanuelle: There could be confusion. On backs of paintings there could be many labels with different titles. Some of these labels might be from exhibitions.
column90: Rob: Other options: Make name its own resource. Problematic because everything is name. Not important that name is text. Back can carry the name separate from title.
column91: Attribute assignment way is difficult b/c do not know much about the actual assignment and conflicts with the exhibition case.

column56: Position of inscriptionshttps://github.com/linked-art/linked.art/issues/348Discuss relative positioning of carried content - out of scope beyond a note?
column57: Rob: If knowing where the inscription is how do we present that in structured data?
column58: Dave: Location info in inscriptions/marks is in text. “Lower left corner”. Not normalized. IIIF images of inscriptions could be included?
column59: Rob: Detail image would work nicely with structured data. Carries inscriptions and has representation of the detail of the object.
column60: Dave/John multiple terms to represent the same quadrant. Same with any vocabulary.
column61: Thanasis: Areas on painting by quadrants could be places not locations?
column62: Dave: Structured form usefulness as opposed to an aide.
column63: Thanasis: Conservation POV annotate from photograph rather than using words. Probably doesn’t apply to signatures.
column64: Rob: 3D images makes it much more complicated.
column65: Richard: Provided example in chat. Same type of location info. In Marks and Inscriptions field. Cataloging completeness can vary.
column66: Rob: Are there sufficient usecases for creating a physical part? Maybe with a separate image of the inscription. Material could be interesting too “signed in ink” on a watercolor.
column67: Thanasis: Partitioning should not be a problem for creation of part. Capacity for having separate material is useful.
column68: Dave: Do we want to require expression of data in both ways when more detailed expression is available?
column69: Rob: Valuable to have both. Because gives easy way to render content to a human. And if there are research questions that arise that query can be run.
column70: Dave: Also for computer readability.
column71: Object State specific dimensionshttps://github.com/linked-art/linked.art/issues/251
column72: Rob: Linked Art and Linked Conservation with its more scientific focus. Want to have ability to record dimensions as well as how the dimensions were obtained. Allows us to put more properties on. Eg Curator, ruler.
column73: We have ability to measure, but do not have a pattern for measuring while an object is in a particular state. Could add property “technique’ that refers to some state of the object. Eg box while open. Technique =  box while open. Unframed, etc.
column74: More complicated when dealing with parts. Overall state of the object gives flexibility for vocabulary term to be used across institutions.
column75: Other proposal would be multiple types. Put on the dimension. Or using state (open, closed). That requires having states which is something we are trying to avoid.
column76: Thanasis: If wanting to compare height without frame you would have to go through attribution assignment technique. For with/without frame. Is there real advantage.
column77: Rob: One issue no “openness” Widthness works but could not match on “open”.
column78: George: Advantage of attribute assignment is there is a problem with grouping dimensions. Attribute assignment lets you say it is “open” even if not knowing agent or time. Can group together which is useful.
column79: Issue of Time based media. (Thanks Karina!).
column80: Thanasis: Attribute assignment gives more flexibility. Good solution.
column81: Rob: This would be just one more field to something we will use quite often.

column51: Vocabularies ( https://github.com/linked-art/linked.art/issues/186 )
column52: In order to create useful profile of CIDOC-CRM we need a set of required vocabulary terms and lists of suggested vocabulary terms to help people be consistent in building implementations on top of their data. Also, to save time in not having to looking in AAT
column53: for terms that are common to us all.
column54: Planned to draw distinction between terms, ones required for compatibility with Linked Art, then some other recommended terms to save time, then some other listed terms just as FYI but not required or recommended.
column55: [Joe has some terms extracted from NGL data that could be added to lists]
column56: https://drive.google.com/file/d/17njjuw90H1Jq51CrQelbe0izogIOZbdn/view?usp=sharing
column57: (Open link but does not need to go everywhere, but not specifically secret :-) )
column58: Required Terms:
column59: Metatypes - For the API.
column60: Object Type (e.g. Attic Krater)
column61: Statement Type
column62: Work Type
column63: Recommended Terms
column64: Listed Terms
column65: Joe - Is this a hierarchy of terms or is it a flat list ?
column66: Rob - Potential issue with the way CRM thinks about these things
column67: Joe - Could use w3id for new identifiers (non-AAT)
column68: Rob - Could make Linked Art namespace term. But hopefully Patricia will add in terms to AAT so we don’t need to create many of our owns.
column69: Antoine - Do we make list mandatory or do we allow new terms if provided with an alignment to the allowed list.
column70: Rob - For metatypes, the list is short so we should not allow new ones (even if they can be ultimately resolved to a known term, due to the overhead in processing)
column71: Antoine - Nervous about promoting a model that forces classification choices on people. If we have the type Text from AAT and someone disagrees about that use for example.
column72: Rob - Agree, but it is only for Types
column73: Antoine - Also concern over language
column74: Rob - To clarify we are talking about the classified_as statement “Type of Work”. This would not be displayed.
column75: Antoine - Confused from the ticket, had thought it was more about SKOS/concepts but is closer to classes.
column76: Rob - Agree, it’s a stand in for relationship
column77: Emmanuelle - Do we need in the documentation more background to why metatypes required/useful.
column78: Rob - Agreed, we need to make decisions on where we do this. We need a page listing the types of types, on the object page the metatype for “Type of Work” etc.
column79: Replacement for Properties
column80: There are a small number of properties. Need to find an easy programmatic way for people get properties such as “Primary Name” for a title.
column81: Joe: Could be more than expected ?
column82: Rob: Have tried to be careful with this. For Dimensions for example list as required but extensible. If you want to say Height use AAT, if you want “Unframed Painting Height” use something else but processors might not know what to do with it.
column83: Joe: Primary Name is the one you would expect processors to use
column84: Rob: Yes, and if there isn’t a primary name then you are free to pick any of the other names available to use.
column85: API Distinguishing terms
column86: For example Provenance Activity and Exhibition Activity we need a flag to be able to distinguish between them, otherwise consuming application won’t know which belongs to which. Need to distinguish between main classes where we have multiple models using the same class.
column87: Started to make the lists, easy to get bogged down as lots of possible terms.
column88: Recommended Terms
column89: Enumerable - Terms we can enumerate but can be extended in some circumstances  (e.g. Parts of personal names)
column90: Ultra-Common Terms - Put together a list of terms such as paintings that everyone can use.
column91: Listed Terms
column92: Big Bucket of Terms. Take your pick. Languages, materials, etc instead of searching through AAT.
column93: Required Terms
column94: Spreadsheet - https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1gyxb9Q31jvF0Zd_BZscqijA20u99FRgCJgDGmRMbPe0/edit#gid=1337687428
column95: How to decide between required and recommended? Will have to just start with educated guesses based on existing systems and
column96: Joe: Should we version this so people can know what version they are compatible with.
column97: Rob: For required, it’s part of Linked Art versioning. For recommendation we should version separately. For listed, it’s not versioned as it’s informational.
column98: Joe: Projects working on try to separate out normally.
column99: Rob: IIIF has had same problem. Used Extensions Registry as way to handle this. Allows Core terms to be in the spec but with ability to extend without needing people to keep having to check.
column100: Rob: Do Required terms go into the model ? E.g. AAT for Primary Name.
column101: Joe: Extension Registry seems a good model. Difficulty could be some people want recommended ones as optional, how would this be allowed ?
column102: Rob: Shouldn’t be updating rapidly but shouldn’t be multi years gaps between updates
column103: Joe: Is a spreadsheet a good format for this ? Could some vocab software be used?
column104: Rob: Not a final documentation, but for working on it
column105: Joe: Not seen any software out that could be dropped into use. Web Protege ? Could use Semantic Mediawiki with templates, could then display as list/tables, etc but have easy editability, probably too much work to really be a benefit though.
column106: Rob: Good for ontologies but for concepts ?
column107: Bree: Has been using it for creating vocabularies, but not sure if it can be plugged into something else. Possibly API access (apart from RDF/spreadsheet download)
column108: Homework: Think about terms used in existing systems and whether they are valuable for interoperability / consistency between systems. column309: Jonathan Lill - Easier to retrospectively attach artists to past exhibitions than to try to discover all the objects that were featured.
column310: Travelling shows more complex  modelling, needs a concept with instances, instances can have parts. Instance matchable to a venue. If more than one showing of an exhibition need a concept to unify them. Show might change slightly at different venues but overall concept remains the same. Need to be able to add detail at any level. E.g. catalogue might be varied for instances with different objects added/removed. Need to be able to attach all people involved in creating an exhibition. Institutional relationships e.g. organisers (staff or freelancers), hosting institution, venue might be different from organising exhibition (e.g. a sculpture show in Central Park or scattered around the city), single exhibition held at multiple institutions, MoMa and PS1 are one institution but that not always reflected in data
column311: David - Exhibition planning, recording objects rejected during exhibition planning process?
column312: Jonathan - That is available in the paper trail but not really recorded in TMS. Limited by TMS, e.g. cannot say exhibition is in a series, that just is put in the title. Cannot record an exhibition is part of a programme. Spring Shows were common in early C20th but all have same title, would be better grouped if possible. Checklist for shows can be incomplete. Objects can be swapped out during a run. Conservation might limit objects display time for an exhibition. Loan agreements might limit some objects being part of a travelling show. Legal issues, assume institution organising has legal custody.
column313: Data Model: Title, Dates, Venue, Organisation.
column314: Object Location - Could map object movement history.

column595: David: re: URIs inside of documents - should they include the authoritative URI for an entity? Is the objective that the authoritative URI would return Linked Art JSON-LD? If not, how/should we create a bridge?
column596: Adam: I would expect to find the information, not necessarily Linked Art (i.e. more human understandable content)
column597: Rob: This is a scenario for museums who already have APIs/URIs - 3 options:
column598: All URIs should be Linked Art URIs (not going to happen)
column599: There are two URIs and the Linked Art URI identifies the LA description of the object. References between the two URIs. This is technically easy but not semantically satisfying.
column600: Content negotiation - you go to THE URI for THE thing and you ask for a specific format (XML, JSON, LA JSON-LD, etc.)
column601: Adam: Does this presume a lot of workflows to set up published data?
column602: Kevin: Third option sounds like it needs a new piece of infrastructure to handle the look-up.
column603: Antoine: this is the content profile negotiation draft spec: https://www.w3.org/TR/dx-prof-conneg/
column604: George: Trying to understand the full complexity - what is the behavior we expect/want? LA dereference, whether main object URI or specific piece of info
column605: Rob: What requirements can we make of the URI? What is the intersection of the requirements and adoption? What requirements can we legitimately make? For example, may not matter if the object name has a dereferencable URI, because that info is accessible via the primary object URI. Important entities would also be dereferencable - people, places, etc.
column606: Adam: I don’t know if I agree with that, for cases where our data is incomplete.
column607: Kevin: Question is whether the URI should dereference to Linked.Art. Regarding what will work in institutions that don’t already have URIs. How do those institutions get from their CMS to published linked data?
column608: Emmanuelle: But in the case of people, would use a vocabulary URI, not a LA URI that I mint.
column609: Rob: There is a model for describing people with LA. https://linked.art/model/actor/
column610: George: Up to the institution publishing the linked data--to mint and maintain their URIs. Have to take into account that if the institutions create a URI, there needs to be some coreferencing, but if pointing to another resource (i.e., VIAF, ULAN) - preference is for option to follow through LA trail to get all info.
column611: Adam: Think it’s legitimate to use existing vocabularies with no further description.
column612: Emmanuelle: Practice in museums isn’t to say “this is what VIAF says about this person, but here is what we say about this person.”
column613: Multiple people: we DO maintain biographies of our own, publish and share those.
column614: Kevin: Linked Art trail ends when you get to vocabulary URI in the JSON-LD.
column615: Rob: At Getty - we want to identify which people have which name forms, where it was found (documented) - wanted to put all of these name forms into ULAN (didn’t happen) - if we weren’t certain which name was primary, didn’t want to make an authoritative statement. Patricia created a branch of ULAN for unidentified/unverified actors, ending up with thousands of unique records representing the instances of that name (actually only 3 known actors with that name, but can’t attribute to one in particular). This was a terrible idea, so we NEED to mint our own identifiers for these people and say what we do know.
column616: Antoine: So question is, do we want to mint these URIs, especially if they do exist “authoritatively” elsewhere?
column617: Kevin: How do we support the intermediate steps of disambiguating and relating entities.
column618: Ethan: That’s the point of SNAC. https://snaccooperative.org/
column619: Kevin: Can’t have the expectation that people will do reconciliation work - this could be a stopper for implementation.
column620: Rob: Let’s identify individual questions that we are actually asking now, prioritize and answer.
column621: Questions:- When existing internal identifiers, should we link to these with LA JSON-LD or dereference?- When existing external identifiers, should we link to these or dereference?- How to distinguish external URIs that will not return Linked Art when dereferenced?- Mapping of LA resource to type- Blank nodes vs. UUID vs. HTTP URL
column622: Adam: Bad idea to link to an external identifier and then say things about it.
column623: Athanasios: Wait - what do we mean when we say “Linked Art URI”?
column624: David: Should make the distinction between a LA implementation URI and another URI that happens to redirect to LA.
column625: Adam: Don’t want to legislate varying practices in how institutions will go about creating and publishing LA.
column626: Kevin: Yes, we want to accommodate them.
column627: Ethan: The question here is what we should include in LA from external URIs (i.e., preferred label)
column628: Dave: If you are producing LA, using external identifiers serves as a bridge to link your data across the web.
column629: Ethan: But in order to exploit all of that, you still need to ingest those URIs, key data points, into your system.
column630: Antoine: Final question - whether things need identifiers that can be used out of their context? i.e., blank nodes.
column631: Kevin: What is the standardized mechanism for encoding the link that will require consumers to go out and get info (when you hit the end of the LA graph) from another resource? Do we put something in there that makes it easy to jump in?
column632: Adam: We would use some kind of content negotiation.
column633: Kevin: Where would that information/relation live?
column634: Adam: In our existing systems for handling that. Not the case for everyone. Maybe some institutions will just have completely independent URIs, no content negotiation.
column635: Dave: Might be useful for identifiers to return all of the options, if an option is not specified in content negotiation. That this entity is available in various formats, with links to those different documents.
column636: Adam: Vicious about adding in any requirements. (barriers to adoption and implementation)
column637: Kevin: If something links out to an external, non-LA resource, how to get the consumer back into the LA graph?
column638: Adam: How you come back depends entirely on where you went. The link back will depend on the external resource.
column639: Rob: Define the simple case, and more difficult case (full control) - where is the point between the two where it moves from easy to difficult?
column640: Adam: That point is when you are trying to describe something that nobody else is describing. Your identifier is the authoritative identifier, and you take responsibility for that.
column641: Kevin: Supplementary authority vs. THE authority vs. SOLE supplementary authority
column642: Rob: In the case where there are no existing identifiers (or not known), this is the simplest case (for the implementer). When you dereference the sole URI, you get the LA JSON-LD and only that. If this doesn’t work, we’ve screwed something up. Should be possible to just put those files on a file system and deliver them, for the simplest implementation.
column643: Antoine: I disagree. There is still the problem where there would be a person to which we wouldn’t have any interest to follow their identifier.
column644: Kevin: Do wish that people are able to traverse the LA URI graph without hitting dead ends, leaving the graph. Needs to be possible.
column645: Antoine: Reality is there are some entities where there is no value in linking.
column646: Kevin: If you have data (whether you’re the only one with that data or not), you will want to and should be able to publish your data.
column647: Adam: Cost will get very high to publish all data, including that which may not have value or is handled by others.
column648: Rob: Going back to Antoine’s question - I would question that there is actually a use case where you wouldn’t want to go to a URI to get info.
column649: Antoine: But the question is SHOULD you always mint a URI for these entities? You may then become the defacto authority responsible for that entity.
column650: Rob: But without URIs for key entities, we lose the wrapper for our data.
column651: Ethan: But if you have two John Smiths, distinct entities, and you know nothing else about them, then minting distinct URIs will accomplish something - disambiguates the two, lacking no other info.
column652: Antoine: but it could be that the John Smiths in your case were actually the same, you didn't know.
column653: Adam: But two blank notes doesn’t indicate that those two John Smiths ARE the same, just that you know the names and they happen to be the same.
column654: Kevin: The issue is whether as an institution you are able to maintain the URIs that you put out there. It is a policy issue of which entities you wish to maintain.
column655: Adam: Worth saying, “here’s the costs of these practices”. Initial cost to implement URIs is low, but grows over time with maintenance.
column656: [discussion of blank nodes vs. institutional URIs]
column657: George: blank nodes --> can’t point to that thing now or at a later time.
column659: Antoine: Something to ask institutions: if all you have is a name, is it worth minting and maintaining a URI? A bridge too far.
column660: Rob: Let’s create a list of top level entities that would require creating URIs.
column661: Human Made Object (ours - NOT exhibitions, depictions)
column662: People (except external authorities, e.g. VIAF, ULAN)
column663: Group (except external authorities, e.g., VIAF, ULAN)
column665: Collection/set (actual collection itself, not the members of it)
column672: Sami: how about when you're publishing an exhibition list and it's not your objects? (qualifier added to HMO above)
column673: Adam: Creating URIs and making statements about them requires clean data.
column674: Rob: [summarizing above list] - If in the data you encounter a URI that identifies a Person, Place, Group, Place, Textual content, then you should expect that at the other end it may not necessarily be Linked Art (likely use of external authorities. For HMOs, Collection/Set, Provenance Event, Visual Content, Digital Object, Event/Period, or Exhibition, you SHOULD expect to get Linked Art (though there will be exceptions).
column675: Rob: When you dereference a LA URI for certain entities, within the returned JSON you would publish other identifiers from external resources.
column676: Athanasios: So, if you have a link to an external authority, you will always get there going through Linked Art.
column677: Antoine: Possibly problematic wording. Future proof our language - we’re saying you will get Linked Art, but should be “you SHOULD expect to be able to get Linked Art”.
column678: Antoine: Question - the links to external resources - are we saying these links should be present in the LA presentation that is dereferenced from the URI? Is it only accessible from dereferencing, or available in the main document. So we're trying to control the verbosity of the "main records"?
column679: Rob: Example - within a Production Event, the carried out by statement would only include the URI, type, and label. Avoid verbosity, as the document for that entity that carried out the production would provide the full information.
column680: David: Question about mechanisms/syntax for referencing external identifiers
column681: Kevin: Implementation choice of whether/where you use an external identifier vs. internal.
column682: Antoine: Why not use directly the recommended identifier (e.g., ULAN) instead of using the internal identifier, if you’re ultimately recommending that the external is the preferred?
column683: Dave: could be a case of an internal identifier that we prefer other people to use as reference.
column684: Rob: Using both says - don’t use OUR identifier for reconciling, use the external identifier for reconciliation.
column685: Rob: [reiterates summary of top level entities listed above]
column686: Adam: So this will be specified in the documentation - that implementations SHOULD publish LA for certain entity types.
column687: Antoine: And your LA would reference other identifiers.
column688: Rob: If you have something to say about the entity. If you don’t have anything to say, would use the external identifier directly.

column50: Issue 307:
column51: Links to External Authorities:
column52: Long thread, summarized by Rob in comments.
column53: Need to choose the “least bad”. Skos:exactMatch as least bad? Has advantages as real URI. Well known vocabulary especially for thesauri. Simple. Does not have problems as owl “sameAs”. There is prov: alternate_of or CRM L54 same-as.
column54: Could go for longer form that ignores the users (people who want to use the data).
column55: Time to get off the fence. ExactMatch?
column56: Kevin: any implemented examples of domain inferencing? Either for or against? Rob: At Getty system uses GraffityB(?) There are some same as matches for languages in AAT. Rob: only experience harmful effects of turning on inferencing. Thanasis: Effort to model with CRM, turning off inferencing because data is not good defeats the point. George, more in favor of creating a new property. Why have a local usage in Linked Data? Rob: no new properties on this sort of scale.
column57: Joe: Would creating a new property would we not just run into a similar problem later?
column58: Thanasis: What is problem with having URI as string in JSON? Rob: Less about the JSON form, will look similar in JSON. Distinction clearer with example:
column60: “Type”: “Person”,
column61: “_label”: “Rembrandt”,
column62: “identified_by”: [
column64: "type": "Identifier",
column65: “classified_as”: “aat:url”,
column66: "value": "http://vocab.getty.edy/ulan/500999999"
column69: Rob: strings in green, URI in blue. Type is a URI, value is a URI. Top 3099999 and bottom 30999999 are different things even if they look similar in JSON. When loading systems, if it did not know it was a string then could treat as URI and then not match ontology. If string not rendered as URI then it could not be used. Thanasis: ID holds URI, could a system be built to recognize that? Rob: Problem is with entity and identifier. Joe: Add what connects the ID, may make the logic easier to see?
column70: George: Dual nature of URI. Issue with equivalence. Need to consider formality versus a series of ad hoc solutions.
column71: Rob: George’s idea for new property. Linked.Art equivalent_of?   Question of prov? Constraints of prov do not seem to be particularly harmful, but not confident of that. Thanasis: Entities in Prov more limited than CRM. Joe: Alternate_of “two descriptions of the same thing” rather than these are the same thing. That is where conflict could be.
column72: Rob: Knock off “alternative of” or Linked art Same as. Could be new property or L54 (from Dig). L54 could have same scope note problem as LA same as? Rob: maybe do poll? Two reasonable options: own property or ExactMatch. Local solution vs generally known with problem. Thanasis: consult with Sig? This is a problem that occurs in every group. Will delay, but maybe useful to consult. Kevin: common class of problem, is there no solution? Or no one has come up with the solution and that does not preclude us from creating the solution. Rob: Skos ExactMatch will not be changed at this point. Joe: This is a core generic problem, maybe it makes sense to continue to work at the moment, but could be replaced with consensus from Sig? Rob: Temporarily (could be a long temp period) to be replaced at Sig. George: this seems like a practical solution.
column73: New property, had most yes votes. Skos ExactMatch only had no votes.
column74: Decision: New property with possible inclusion into CRM base with Sig later.
column75: Issue 283: Digital extension.
column76: Do we want to fully model digital. Have that be required?
column77: Most frequent examples. 	Link to image that depicts object
column78: Link to document that describes object
column79: Link to IIIF images
column80: All agree to be able to describe these concepts.
column81: Requirements that can complicate things.
column82: One image can depict several different objects.
column83: One book can be about hundreds of objects.
column84: Same image can be carried by digital and physical entities. (printed out Word doc example).
column85: Joe: question of nested images (eg here is an image of a file). Rob should be fine through partitioning.
column86: List of 7 requirements from github issue:
column87: (1) Same digital entity can depict / be about multiple entities
column88: (2) Same image/text can be shown / carried by both physical and digital entities
column89: (3) Same image/text can have multiple digital entities (e.g. same content, different format, different resolution, etc)
column90: (4) If the digital entity has its own API record, then the URI of the record IS NOT the URI of the content but instead needs to reference it
column91: (5) Consuming application can distinguish between documents and images
column92: (6) Consuming application can distinguish between human and machine intended documents (e.g. PDF vs XML/CSV record)
column93: (7) URIs are URIs, not strings.
column94: To think about for next time: three possible ways to do this:
column95: 1 on whiteboard:
column96: 2 slightly simpler is to cut out the identifier
column97: 3 Baseline simplest is representation but does not fulfill all use cases (eg IIIF).

column51: Summary of last week’s mapping call:
column52: Kevin: good call. Example from the Rijksmuseum with Rob performing live OmniGraffling which raised a few issues regarding how the API sits with the model. Same exemplar continues next week.
column53: Joe: have been doing more work on own GitHub system which helps generate Mermaid diagrams from committed models. Would be interested in putting together config for colours and shapes for Linked Art. Currently built from a text file containing a simple set of tab separated triples. https://jpadfield.github.io/simple-modelling/ (docs being built)
column54: Rob: Edward and Rob have also been playing around with live-modelling/diagramming Python tooling (see Showcase1 repo)
column55: Model issues:
column56: #346: membership of arbitrary sets
column57: All the API responses should be able to have membership of a set resource. Object part of collection. Place part of travel route set. Person part of set of people (as opposed to a Group).
column58: However, we haven’t really talked about Sets much, and relationship with other entities.
column59: `member_of` is already a CRM property for constituting groups; so we could re-use the term via JSON-LD mapping.
column60: Thanasis: re: non-physical and physical auction items discussion at Oxford - this felt a little too specific at the time, but Rob’s outline (about) summarises the use cases well. Own opinion is that the semantics need explanations as to why things have been put together.
column61: Rob: mixed physicality sets could be solved with their own class, but this isn’t a case where a Place would be part of the set. This might be too specific. And require reactive modelling to arising use cases.
column62: Thanasis: appreciate that ongoing re-modelling discussions can’t happen too frequently.
column63: Rob: in the ontology we could note: although the range is an E1, we expect it to be used with E22s (and other entities). In theory then, you could use a Set for anything: Places with Types (which makes no sense whatsoever); but in practice people won’t do this. So don’t prohibit weirdness.
column64: Joe: grouping collection things arbitrarily, especially in relation to things which aren’t art objects, in CRM… a collection of use cases put forward as part of the Linked Art 3 project proposal. Modelling the collection may require modelling of other things: the people in this meeting only came from such-and-such specialty.
column65: Rob: only a limited number of concepts in scope: these are the other API endpoints. Any of these (with the possible exception of Places?) seem like they could usefully be in a Set of entities. Restricting a composition of Places and Digital Objects seems unhelpful.
column66: Joe: conceptual things?
column67: Rob: it has to be a Textual thing.
column68: Joe: how about the Set of terms which we should not use to describe our objects because they are objectionable?
column69: Joe: subject matter and keywords are notions people will want to use.
column70: Rob: seems like a meta-issue. It’s not describing the objects but the metadata about the objections.
column71: Joe: a set of types: all of these paintings relate to trees; these to water. Fire, Water, Earth relate to the elements. Keywords are often the links software needs to use to connect things.
column72: Rob: in favour of moving forwards with this. There are good use cases for collecting a mix of concepts together in Sets. Would anyone be disappointed if we permitted any Linked Art primary entities being part of a Set?
column73: Joe: the limitation of CIDOC was that you couldn’t combine sets of things.
column74: Rob: CRM doesn’t support our primary use-case of physical and non-physical things.
column75: Thanasis: we need to recognise that a property that connects anything to anything else is not particularly useful for anything deep. But it does cover our use cases very well..
column76: Joe: possible that people will shortcut proper semantics by using Set.
column77: Rob: so we shouldn’t use this as a stand-in for a real relationship.
column78: Joe: examples will help, showing both Set use and nicely-semantically-describe relations.
column79: Thanasis: don’t want it to be a workaround for complex modelling that you want people to do.
column80: Kevin: some of these slightly arbitrary Sets are tending towards being out-of-scope, even though the use-cases are well founded.
column81: George: where does this fit into CIDOC-CRM? If it is more or less like a list, ontologically, -- ah it’s a PropositionalObject -- that’s fine, we just need a nice scope note for this. We need to be clear that you wouldn’t use it for a group of people (they have Group).
column82: #357: cause of death
column83: Rob: people can die, and that’s part of the Person record; but the cause of death is an Event.
column84: Joe: is this only people and not other things? A Group or Organisation could die. Maybe a stretch of the definition but the process is the same. Would this follow this semantic pattern?
column85: Rob: same relationship applied to the dissolution of the group, or the destruction of the whatever.
column86: ?: death of a racehorse? (not getting notified of who is speaking)
column87: Rob: CRM is not good at animals. We have tended to stay away from describing living creatures who are not people.
column88: Joe: Titian’s Death of Action (sp.)? Represents event in the painting.
column89: Thanasis: we do have BiologicalObject in the CRM.
column90: Rob: we can declare the cause of the destruction of objects; but we cannot give the cause of death of a person. Death() currently only has time and place.
column91: Joe: it’s quite common for people to want to describe what materials killed artists: lead poisoning, mercury poisoning, etc. Also see death of Robert Hayden.
column92: Joe: can the Death occur during an event?
column93: Rob: following the destruction pattern - it was caused by another event. The death did not occur during the stabbing, but the stabbing caused the person to die.
column94: Rob: relatively easy to add cause property with range of another Event entity. The cost isn’t high, but if it’s not going to be useful then we shouldn’t do it.
column95: Joe: unlikely for people to want to model old age as a cause of death.
column96: Edward: relationship is just caused not caused death by?
column97: Rob: Yes
column98: Joe: this pattern could be used for many other things.
column99: Rob: yes, we use it for the Production of objects too. The Production was caused by commission. Current property is `O13`. I don’t think the cognitive cost for following this pattern is very high; there’s no added cost for understanding. There is a low cost for API and model documentation. Although we don’t have data in big collection management systems, it does seem worth the minimum cost of implementation.
column100: Thanasis: the `caused_by` property looks to be using CRMsci. I think that triggered by applies to events which do not have agency. We should double check if we are using this for events with agency.
column101: Joe: would this mean that a house being burned down because some lava flowed into it - would be compatible with the model; but someone pouring petrol on it and setting alight - would not.
column102: Rob: if it works for events then it should work for activities. It doesn’t say only for use with E5s and not E7s.
column103: Thanasis: there was discussion of this in relation to causality. Causality is hard to prove so we opted to make it more general.
column104: Joe: we could preface all of the properties with is currently believed to…
column105: Thanasis: intent. Re: chaos theory. There was no intent on the actor’s behalf to cause something; nevertheless, it did happen. The intent was lacking.
column106: Joe: modelling intent then may need additional commentary.
column107: #355: cultural sensitivity fields
column108: Richard: added this to discussion as aware. The very labelling of the topic itself may be a discussion being had also.
column109: Richard: in light of current events and awarenesses, we are going to be re-cataloguing and marking cultural sensitivity: what and why. At first this may be text, but linked from the issue is a vocabulary for making statements of this kind..
column110: Richard: also data relating to who would have been able to see/interact with an object.
column111: ?: At the McCord (sp?) there are objects which need to be covered at night; can only be shown during certain seasons. There is information for this in the acquisition records but not in the ontology.
column112: Rob: there should be a set of controlled values?
column113: Richard: ideally yes, although we may begin with a textual statement.
column114: Richard: Kevin, maybe say something towards this being rolled into a future project strand?
column115: Joe: Tate looking at extending project funding for implementing further vocabulary detoxing.
column116: ?: what about using PROV (from W3C) to record that things were stated at a certain time; rather than continually revisiting the data and bringing into line with current culture.
column117: Joe: the ability to capture mixed or conflicting beliefs would be wonderful. But if there are objects which have restrictions on use, how can we make this data searchable/usable/findable to a user and not just a historian of the data.
column118: Kevin: we have proposed to AHRC to look at how institutions are approaching this work and examine what is recorded in the data. There’s potentially interesting work here: to try and understand how this maps into institutional mission and whether the data can support it. Then how this is modelled, etc., is complicated.
column119: Rob: we have shied away from modelling how people’s beliefs have changed over time. No one has the data and it becomes very complicated very quickly.
column120: George: re implementation suggestion comment in issue: P2 is not right; maybe Name Use? This thing was categorised by this curator at this time and it had this now not-kocher-to-use term. Similarly: this other group doesn’t classify things as the curators do, but they consider that it has this other meaning.

Ideal strand would be for that knowledge to intersect with an institution interested in developing LA as a technology. Richard: provenance would be doable? There are established people. column60: Model issues:
column61: Professional Activity vs Professionhttps://github.com/linked-art/linked.art/issues/351Proposal - Add a metatype to specific professional activities, and keep professional activity as well (c.f. artwork / type of work)
column62: Rob: Should we do same sort of pattern as artwork and type of object. Two types done professionally and what type. Would give all possibilities. Eg Profession architect; architecting without being professional, or profession without knowing what type.
column63: Joe: Would this logic be enough to classify someone as an artist, painter, architect etc.?
column64: Rob: should be enough.
column65: Joe: Clear understanding as how to query this would be helpful.
column66: Rob: Lewis Carroll example, artist/author (among lots of others) this pattern allows for all activities, professional or not.
column67: Joe: How to get to “Lewis Carroll” from this in LA.
column68: Rob: {
column69: "type": "Person",
column70: "performed": {
column71: "type": "Activity",
column72: "classified_as": [
column73: {"id": "aat:300393177", "type": "Type", "_label": "Professional Activities"},
column74: {"id": "aat:300024987", "type": "Type", "_label": "Architecting", "classified_as": {"id": "aat:type-of-activity", "type": "Type", "_label": "Type of Activity"}}
column77: Philippe: Can use professional activities twice? Rob: Yes. Philippe: query becomes more complicated. Rob: need to know it is professional and architecting.
column78: Joe: How to get from the event (a larger event with multiple people) to the activity?
column79: Rob: from API point of view, do not have arbitrary activities at top level. Would put the activity under the person.
column80: Rob: this case is to find all the artists and/or all the collectors and they can be one in the same person.
column81: Joe: in the case of exhibition how to connect multiple people? Rob: that could be tricky. Dave: relationship with objects?
column82: Joe: another model test, person with professional paintings and amateur paintings?
column83: Kevin and Joe: question of large project over time with multiple projects. Complex query to find architects involved in creating National Gallery for example. Rob: could be associated with National Gallery as building not as a project. Joe: do not want to encode the same data multiple times.
column84: Bree question of timespan, Rob included in model.
column85: Non specific timespans? First part of century? Rob: all to the second but with fuzziness. Ontology does give flexibility with uncertain timespans. Also can say abstract period of time “Bronze Age” and activity took place in that period without saying when that abstract period is. As long as people know when the abstract period took place.
column86: Rob: Will write up into the person model for double checking. Can cover use cases without stretching anything.
column87: Identifier context https://github.com/linked-art/linked.art/issues/347
column88: Rob: Objects move around and get identified in different ways by different people.
column89: Accession number example. 1997 acc number but there is a pre-1997 number. Need to know earlier museum or would have two identical acc numbers in model.
column90: Joe: Identifier assigned by legal entity. Can this be a third party identifier? Rob: Could be a good case.
column91: Rob: solution is “assigned by”. Based on the id of the museum or other assigner. Lugt number would also fit in here.
column92: Joe: Multiple acc numbers from one institution? National Gallery exhibition gets x number. Sample gets r number. Long term loan gets L number. Purchased gets NG number. An object could have all those numbers depending on history.
column93: : Metatype of Accession Number? Rob: May not solve Joe’s question.
column94: Rob: Is “general_purpose” enough? Does it give the intent of accession number?
column95: Dave: May be more appropriate to record exhibition numbers with exh, not object. Rob: Doesn’t solve long-term loan,
column96: For artist numbers that is solved on the group level. Question is about multiple numbers from one institution.
column97: Joe: Makes query harder. Could look for all accession numbers an filter. Dave: History of accession numbers. Rob: History is easier can put a timespan on it. Not for valid but rather for when it was assigned.
column98: Joe: Case of acc number and Group number. Group numbers also NG numbers.
column99: Rob: Is group different physical thing with its own numbers?
column100: Rob: Basic scenario of who assignes acc number this model is good. We did add other features without problems in model. Can we move forward on this?
column101: Edward’s question about publication. Rob yes: “is_referred_to-by”
column102: Kevin: Purchase case, is that similar to groups? Sub-division of lots? Maybe use this pattern? Joe’s examples may need to be revisited. The shared acc numbers may not have to be part of LA 1.0, if not very common.
column103: Rob: Will put out agenda earlier.

column67: Model issues
column69: Inscriptions and signations.
column70: There is a distinction between a statement about an inscription signature or the inscription/signature itself.
column71: Rob: we have statements already, but we don’t have documentation explaining how to model the actual signature. There are two approaches:
column72: Have the VisualItem of the work represent the LinguisticObject which is the actual inscription
column73: Have the inscription being carried_by the object itself
column74: The trade-off is that we can make comments (in #1) about the qualities of the inscription (it’s blue, or tilted); where as (#2) gives fewer affordances.
column75: Michiel: is the carries property already used for artwork-type patterns or only books?
column76: Rob: not in any of the documentation. So far only for book-like things. I could imagine that a sculpture with a carved inscription or a painting with significant text within the painting, or the words on a building -- all of these things would be text carried by an object. Therefore it’s not going to be uncommon. Although… will museum contributors have the appropriate data in their CMS?
column77: Michiel: what exactly is a VisualItem? Can the VisualItem also carry?
column78: Rob: carries is for the relationship between a physical thing and a textual thing. Whereas represents is more -- what is represented in the visual content. Represents is right here.
column79: Michiel: so a LinguisticObject can be in the range of represents?
column80: Rob: yes. Even non-physical things.
column81: Joe: if you want to document detail about signature then there are likely issues with simply recording a piece of text. Complexity: multiple signatures, obscured, incomplete, removed, etc. From a conservation point of view, there’s difficulty with it simply being text and a number.
column82: Rob: VisualItem would be beneficial here as the text might be Vinc and the -ent was lost.
column83: Joe: the signature is also a physical thing. It’s made of something.
column84: Rob: yes, the materials of the paint of the signature would require a physical HMO to represent the signature.
column85: Michiel: if there is a person depicted. You might want to say it’s been done with thick paint. Maybe this is going too far?
column86: Joe: there’s a difference between a depiction of a person (they are not in the painting) but the signature is there.
column87: Rob: Emmanuelle also commented on a date being present. Either of the suggested patterns work for these circumstances.
column88: Joe: when a photograph has been taken of the signature, where does it hang?
column89: George: depicts more appropriate than carries for visual but needs to be balanced between pragmatic use of data. Creating VisualItem blank nodes for the sake of good modelling might actually lead to confusion if you never have any claims to make about it. Sometimes this might be better tagged as the aspect of the object.
column90: Rob: we have tried to avoid shortcuts wherever possible. Given that there are lots of use cases for the visual work part, I would personally prefer not to introduce a shortcut on this.
column91: George: if normally you’d pass this sort of information through the VisualItem, then using P128_carries would be inconsistent.
column92: Emmanuelle: it’s not unusual for new inscriptions to be acquired/discovered, and it’s important to capture them. We might describe the date when an inscription was made based on its materials.
column93: Michiel: labels of auction house, transporters, and so on. These can be affixed to the rear of a painting. Is VisualItem inappropriate for handling all the positional information in this context?
column94: For example:
column95: inscription: “painted in red ink”, position: left bottom side. Inscription has creator. As well as the content of the inscription.
column96: Watermark: type, creator [empty], description: a shield with a crown holding a scimitar (etc. Latin etc.)
column97: Rob: let’s take positioning first. We have found, in conservation, where somethings is/happened is significant. George and Rob have used a polygon, which gets applied to an image which overlays the position of the inscription. We could have the VisualItem represent the inscription and then it could have position.
column98: Michiel: this would add another object: artwork has physical part which has VisualItem.
column99: Rob: physical part is made of blue paint; the VisualItem part has position and description and it represents “Vincent” as text.
column100: Michiel: the parts could then also have materials?
column101: Rob: yes, this could all go on to the physical part.
column102: Joe: relative physical dimensions?
column103: Rob: we need Thanasis.
column104: Joe: how would you define a panel in an altarpiece? It’s a painting within a sculpture.
column105: Rob: yes, and then recursive parts: the left panel has whatever characteristics…
column106: Michiel: couldn’t the physical part then just carry this inscription and we do away with the VisualItem?
column107: Rob: visual works have some notion of space and layout but text doesn’t. So you need it for positioning. The altarpiece example is a good one. But describing the nested complexities of it in realtime was too much for the notetaker.
column108: Michel: have asked to share examples from the Van Gogh Museum. Will post on GitHub when permitted.
column109: Rob: will also do Irises.

column88: Kevin: do we separate between models and apis? Clean part of the separation of what is expected from the resource. There could be a clean separation when you identify the principle of when there would be a more specialized model/partition from the main data
column89: Having a clear view on the conceptual model is ‘relatively’ easy. But the transition to implementation in an api is about agreeing principles of practice.

column91: How to know from which endpoint you get the more information? E.g. between a Linked Art dimension pattern which just has a little bit of dimension data and the LCD dimension point which would have a rich amount of information.
