column595: David: re: URIs inside of documents - should they include the authoritative URI for an entity? Is the objective that the authoritative URI would return Linked Art JSON-LD? If not, how/should we create a bridge?
column596: Adam: I would expect to find the information, not necessarily Linked Art (i.e. more human understandable content)
column597: Rob: This is a scenario for museums who already have APIs/URIs - 3 options:
column598: All URIs should be Linked Art URIs (not going to happen)
column599: There are two URIs and the Linked Art URI identifies the LA description of the object. References between the two URIs. This is technically easy but not semantically satisfying.
column600: Content negotiation - you go to THE URI for THE thing and you ask for a specific format (XML, JSON, LA JSON-LD, etc.)
column601: Adam: Does this presume a lot of workflows to set up published data?
column602: Kevin: Third option sounds like it needs a new piece of infrastructure to handle the look-up.
column603: Antoine: this is the content profile negotiation draft spec: https://www.w3.org/TR/dx-prof-conneg/
column604: George: Trying to understand the full complexity - what is the behavior we expect/want? LA dereference, whether main object URI or specific piece of info
column605: Rob: What requirements can we make of the URI? What is the intersection of the requirements and adoption? What requirements can we legitimately make? For example, may not matter if the object name has a dereferencable URI, because that info is accessible via the primary object URI. Important entities would also be dereferencable - people, places, etc.
column606: Adam: I don’t know if I agree with that, for cases where our data is incomplete.
column607: Kevin: Question is whether the URI should dereference to Linked.Art. Regarding what will work in institutions that don’t already have URIs. How do those institutions get from their CMS to published linked data?
column608: Emmanuelle: But in the case of people, would use a vocabulary URI, not a LA URI that I mint.
column609: Rob: There is a model for describing people with LA. https://linked.art/model/actor/
column610: George: Up to the institution publishing the linked data--to mint and maintain their URIs. Have to take into account that if the institutions create a URI, there needs to be some coreferencing, but if pointing to another resource (i.e., VIAF, ULAN) - preference is for option to follow through LA trail to get all info.
column611: Adam: Think it’s legitimate to use existing vocabularies with no further description.
column612: Emmanuelle: Practice in museums isn’t to say “this is what VIAF says about this person, but here is what we say about this person.”
column613: Multiple people: we DO maintain biographies of our own, publish and share those.
column614: Kevin: Linked Art trail ends when you get to vocabulary URI in the JSON-LD.
column615: Rob: At Getty - we want to identify which people have which name forms, where it was found (documented) - wanted to put all of these name forms into ULAN (didn’t happen) - if we weren’t certain which name was primary, didn’t want to make an authoritative statement. Patricia created a branch of ULAN for unidentified/unverified actors, ending up with thousands of unique records representing the instances of that name (actually only 3 known actors with that name, but can’t attribute to one in particular). This was a terrible idea, so we NEED to mint our own identifiers for these people and say what we do know.
column616: Antoine: So question is, do we want to mint these URIs, especially if they do exist “authoritatively” elsewhere?
column617: Kevin: How do we support the intermediate steps of disambiguating and relating entities.
column618: Ethan: That’s the point of SNAC. https://snaccooperative.org/
column619: Kevin: Can’t have the expectation that people will do reconciliation work - this could be a stopper for implementation.
column620: Rob: Let’s identify individual questions that we are actually asking now, prioritize and answer.
column621: Questions:- When existing internal identifiers, should we link to these with LA JSON-LD or dereference?- When existing external identifiers, should we link to these or dereference?- How to distinguish external URIs that will not return Linked Art when dereferenced?- Mapping of LA resource to type- Blank nodes vs. UUID vs. HTTP URL
column622: Adam: Bad idea to link to an external identifier and then say things about it.
column623: Athanasios: Wait - what do we mean when we say “Linked Art URI”?
column624: David: Should make the distinction between a LA implementation URI and another URI that happens to redirect to LA.
column625: Adam: Don’t want to legislate varying practices in how institutions will go about creating and publishing LA.
column626: Kevin: Yes, we want to accommodate them.
column627: Ethan: The question here is what we should include in LA from external URIs (i.e., preferred label)
column628: Dave: If you are producing LA, using external identifiers serves as a bridge to link your data across the web.
column629: Ethan: But in order to exploit all of that, you still need to ingest those URIs, key data points, into your system.
column630: Antoine: Final question - whether things need identifiers that can be used out of their context? i.e., blank nodes.
column631: Kevin: What is the standardized mechanism for encoding the link that will require consumers to go out and get info (when you hit the end of the LA graph) from another resource? Do we put something in there that makes it easy to jump in?
column632: Adam: We would use some kind of content negotiation.
column633: Kevin: Where would that information/relation live?
column634: Adam: In our existing systems for handling that. Not the case for everyone. Maybe some institutions will just have completely independent URIs, no content negotiation.
column635: Dave: Might be useful for identifiers to return all of the options, if an option is not specified in content negotiation. That this entity is available in various formats, with links to those different documents.
column636: Adam: Vicious about adding in any requirements. (barriers to adoption and implementation)
column637: Kevin: If something links out to an external, non-LA resource, how to get the consumer back into the LA graph?
column638: Adam: How you come back depends entirely on where you went. The link back will depend on the external resource.
column639: Rob: Define the simple case, and more difficult case (full control) - where is the point between the two where it moves from easy to difficult?
column640: Adam: That point is when you are trying to describe something that nobody else is describing. Your identifier is the authoritative identifier, and you take responsibility for that.
column641: Kevin: Supplementary authority vs. THE authority vs. SOLE supplementary authority
column642: Rob: In the case where there are no existing identifiers (or not known), this is the simplest case (for the implementer). When you dereference the sole URI, you get the LA JSON-LD and only that. If this doesn’t work, we’ve screwed something up. Should be possible to just put those files on a file system and deliver them, for the simplest implementation.
column643: Antoine: I disagree. There is still the problem where there would be a person to which we wouldn’t have any interest to follow their identifier.
column644: Kevin: Do wish that people are able to traverse the LA URI graph without hitting dead ends, leaving the graph. Needs to be possible.
column645: Antoine: Reality is there are some entities where there is no value in linking.
column646: Kevin: If you have data (whether you’re the only one with that data or not), you will want to and should be able to publish your data.
column647: Adam: Cost will get very high to publish all data, including that which may not have value or is handled by others.
column648: Rob: Going back to Antoine’s question - I would question that there is actually a use case where you wouldn’t want to go to a URI to get info.
column649: Antoine: But the question is SHOULD you always mint a URI for these entities? You may then become the defacto authority responsible for that entity.
column650: Rob: But without URIs for key entities, we lose the wrapper for our data.
column651: Ethan: But if you have two John Smiths, distinct entities, and you know nothing else about them, then minting distinct URIs will accomplish something - disambiguates the two, lacking no other info.
column652: Antoine: but it could be that the John Smiths in your case were actually the same, you didn't know.
column653: Adam: But two blank notes doesn’t indicate that those two John Smiths ARE the same, just that you know the names and they happen to be the same.
column654: Kevin: The issue is whether as an institution you are able to maintain the URIs that you put out there. It is a policy issue of which entities you wish to maintain.
column655: Adam: Worth saying, “here’s the costs of these practices”. Initial cost to implement URIs is low, but grows over time with maintenance.
column656: [discussion of blank nodes vs. institutional URIs]
column657: George: blank nodes --> can’t point to that thing now or at a later time.
column659: Antoine: Something to ask institutions: if all you have is a name, is it worth minting and maintaining a URI? A bridge too far.
column660: Rob: Let’s create a list of top level entities that would require creating URIs.
column661: Human Made Object (ours - NOT exhibitions, depictions)
column662: People (except external authorities, e.g. VIAF, ULAN)
column663: Group (except external authorities, e.g., VIAF, ULAN)
column665: Collection/set (actual collection itself, not the members of it)
column672: Sami: how about when you're publishing an exhibition list and it's not your objects? (qualifier added to HMO above)
column673: Adam: Creating URIs and making statements about them requires clean data.
column674: Rob: [summarizing above list] - If in the data you encounter a URI that identifies a Person, Place, Group, Place, Textual content, then you should expect that at the other end it may not necessarily be Linked Art (likely use of external authorities. For HMOs, Collection/Set, Provenance Event, Visual Content, Digital Object, Event/Period, or Exhibition, you SHOULD expect to get Linked Art (though there will be exceptions).
column675: Rob: When you dereference a LA URI for certain entities, within the returned JSON you would publish other identifiers from external resources.
column676: Athanasios: So, if you have a link to an external authority, you will always get there going through Linked Art.
column677: Antoine: Possibly problematic wording. Future proof our language - we’re saying you will get Linked Art, but should be “you SHOULD expect to be able to get Linked Art”.
column678: Antoine: Question - the links to external resources - are we saying these links should be present in the LA presentation that is dereferenced from the URI? Is it only accessible from dereferencing, or available in the main document. So we're trying to control the verbosity of the "main records"?
column679: Rob: Example - within a Production Event, the carried out by statement would only include the URI, type, and label. Avoid verbosity, as the document for that entity that carried out the production would provide the full information.
column680: David: Question about mechanisms/syntax for referencing external identifiers
column681: Kevin: Implementation choice of whether/where you use an external identifier vs. internal.
column682: Antoine: Why not use directly the recommended identifier (e.g., ULAN) instead of using the internal identifier, if you’re ultimately recommending that the external is the preferred?
column683: Dave: could be a case of an internal identifier that we prefer other people to use as reference.
column684: Rob: Using both says - don’t use OUR identifier for reconciling, use the external identifier for reconciliation.
column685: Rob: [reiterates summary of top level entities listed above]
column686: Adam: So this will be specified in the documentation - that implementations SHOULD publish LA for certain entity types.
column687: Antoine: And your LA would reference other identifiers.
column688: Rob: If you have something to say about the entity. If you don’t have anything to say, would use the external identifier directly.
column689: David: Should you drop the Type assertion on an external identifier?
column691: Rob: Simple case - script to transform source data to JSON-LD; system that handles content negotiation
column692: Rob: When there are multiple representations (less simple case), the client needs to know how to request a specific format
column693: Adam: Would like to see “shoulds” become “mays” in the documentation
column694: Kevin: Scenario: your institution already has a URI, do you put that into your LA JSON-LD, or do you use that URI and via content negotiation LA JSON-LD or other return can be requested?
column696: Rob: If there are other avoidances that we want to associate with URI, it would be much trickier within the content negotiation case than otherwise. Example: structuring a request to return all incoming references to the URI instead of returning outgoing.
column697: Rob: Should we recommend a form of URI? No.
column698: Sami: some recipes on structuring URIs could be useful for some implementers.
column699: Rob: Probably shouldn’t use a blank node, but how about a non-dereferencable identifier (i.e., UUID)
column700: General: As long as the UUID is stable.
column701: George: Need consistency in identifiers. Maintain a consistent method to produce these identifiers.
column702: Antoine: But the John Smith example from before could end up with the same hash.
column703: Adam: How many qualities/pieces of information should you have to publish a URI or other unique identifier that would require maintenance?
column704: Antoine: Return to my refusal to identify these things when there isn’t information or valuable information. In those cases, if the person has no identity outside of the context of that object, what about using a URI like .../object/person
column705: Richard: But most institutions have system identifiers for person entities.
column707: Antoine: If LA requires identifiers, it should be simple to mint them, even for institutions that may not have system identifiers. Prefer blank nodes, but if the URIs must be minted, make it simple to do.
column708: Edward: Does one institution's desire to mint a fragment URI instead of a real one impede a user’s ability to find information about these entities?
column709: Antoine: When more information is found out, a new more legitimate URI would be minted, and be related to the old one that has been deprecated
column710: Edward: Why have two different practices for minting URIs - whether fragment or direct, if you need a URI do it consistently. CIDOC’s Statement on Linked Data identifiers for museum objects:   http://network.icom.museum/fileadmin/user_upload/minisites/cidoc/PDF/StatementOnLinkedDataIdentifiersForMuseumObjects.pdf
column711: Adam: Question is actually whether we have a URI (any URI) or not (blank node).
column712: David: NGA went with UUIDs, storing them in the CMS, so that data will always go along with all the other data should there be a migration. More sustainable approach than using CMS db identifiers.
column714: With clever systems, you can implement a single URI which can return many different representations.
column715: Recent W3C discussions have produced guidelines for implementing content negotiation. Both are viable:
column718: IETF have not ruled that profiles should resolve to a particular pattern. However, neither is forbidden.  https://www.w3.org/TR/json-ld11/#iana-considerations
column719: The profile parameter is already in use.
column720: The profile may be being used to describe either the content or the container. Which blurs the situation.
column721: Another consideration is the ability to register a file type against a profile. We could, therefore, propose a filename pattern and register it so that a browser could automatically handle it. Something like `.lajson` (or whatever).
column722: Dave: do web servers support these application profiles?
column723: Adam: yes; Apache certainly does. Luckily there are strict rules for comparing MIME types.
column724: Given the possibility that IETF dislike the repeating plus characters, Rob suggests using the hash pattern URI.
column725: Antoine: possibly we should wait for the developing recommendations for application profile (not in media types) in general to conclude? ~ Maybe: https://www.w3.org/TR/dx-prof-conneg/
column726: Rob: if we want a different syntax but the same structure (Turtle instead of JSON-LD) then there’s a conflict - we would have to use a special header. As Linked Art is a JSON-LD shop then we don’t have to specify.
column727: Antoine: there’s vagueness between profiles and form which either describes format or content structure. The discussion between the two W3C groups resulted in a nice outcime, ie. JSON-LD "profiles" are rather about the "form" of the data than its content.
column728: Antoine: relating to the urgency of this -- is Linked Art JSON-LD competing with other forms of JSON-LD in the community at the moment? Can we use /json-ld and wait until there is a conflict? Ethan/Rob: no, we are already using JSON-LD for other data.
column729: Kevin (to Rob): are you going to implement both or one (of these profile choices)? Rob: Getty will implement the group’s recommendation.
column730: The `#profile` is in the JSON-LD context, but the `+` route does not allow representing Linked Art in other data formats.

column71: Rob: George’s idea for new property. Linked.Art equivalent_of?   Question of prov? Constraints of prov do not seem to be particularly harmful, but not confident of that. Thanasis: Entities in Prov more limited than CRM. Joe: Alternate_of “two descriptions of the same thing” rather than these are the same thing. That is where conflict could be.
column72: Rob: Knock off “alternative of” or Linked art Same as. Could be new property or L54 (from Dig). L54 could have same scope note problem as LA same as? Rob: maybe do poll? Two reasonable options: own property or ExactMatch. Local solution vs generally known with problem. Thanasis: consult with Sig? This is a problem that occurs in every group. Will delay, but maybe useful to consult. Kevin: common class of problem, is there no solution? Or no one has come up with the solution and that does not preclude us from creating the solution. Rob: Skos ExactMatch will not be changed at this point. Joe: This is a core generic problem, maybe it makes sense to continue to work at the moment, but could be replaced with consensus from Sig? Rob: Temporarily (could be a long temp period) to be replaced at Sig. George: this seems like a practical solution.
column73: New property, had most yes votes. Skos ExactMatch only had no votes.
column74: Decision: New property with possible inclusion into CRM base with Sig later.
column75: Issue 283: Digital extension.
column76: Do we want to fully model digital. Have that be required?
column77: Most frequent examples. 	Link to image that depicts object
column78: Link to document that describes object
column79: Link to IIIF images
column80: All agree to be able to describe these concepts.
column81: Requirements that can complicate things.
column82: One image can depict several different objects.
column83: One book can be about hundreds of objects.
column84: Same image can be carried by digital and physical entities. (printed out Word doc example).
column85: Joe: question of nested images (eg here is an image of a file). Rob should be fine through partitioning.
column86: List of 7 requirements from github issue:
column87: (1) Same digital entity can depict / be about multiple entities
column88: (2) Same image/text can be shown / carried by both physical and digital entities
column89: (3) Same image/text can have multiple digital entities (e.g. same content, different format, different resolution, etc)
column90: (4) If the digital entity has its own API record, then the URI of the record IS NOT the URI of the content but instead needs to reference it
column91: (5) Consuming application can distinguish between documents and images
column92: (6) Consuming application can distinguish between human and machine intended documents (e.g. PDF vs XML/CSV record)
column93: (7) URIs are URIs, not strings.
column94: To think about for next time: three possible ways to do this:
column95: 1 on whiteboard:
column96: 2 slightly simpler is to cut out the identifier
column97: 3 Baseline simplest is representation but does not fulfill all use cases (eg IIIF).

column29: Join from PC, Mac, Linux, iOS or Android: https://yale.zoom.us/j/95966493735
column50: Kevin: circulated documents last Friday. Would welcome attention and contributions relating to leadership.
column51: Summary of last week’s mapping call:
column52: Kevin: good call. Example from the Rijksmuseum with Rob performing live OmniGraffling which raised a few issues regarding how the API sits with the model. Same exemplar continues next week.
column53: Joe: have been doing more work on own GitHub system which helps generate Mermaid diagrams from committed models. Would be interested in putting together config for colours and shapes for Linked Art. Currently built from a text file containing a simple set of tab separated triples. https://jpadfield.github.io/simple-modelling/ (docs being built)
column54: Rob: Edward and Rob have also been playing around with live-modelling/diagramming Python tooling (see Showcase1 repo)
column55: Model issues:
column56: #346: membership of arbitrary sets
column57: All the API responses should be able to have membership of a set resource. Object part of collection. Place part of travel route set. Person part of set of people (as opposed to a Group).
column58: However, we haven’t really talked about Sets much, and relationship with other entities.
column59: `member_of` is already a CRM property for constituting groups; so we could re-use the term via JSON-LD mapping.
column60: Thanasis: re: non-physical and physical auction items discussion at Oxford - this felt a little too specific at the time, but Rob’s outline (about) summarises the use cases well. Own opinion is that the semantics need explanations as to why things have been put together.
column61: Rob: mixed physicality sets could be solved with their own class, but this isn’t a case where a Place would be part of the set. This might be too specific. And require reactive modelling to arising use cases.
column62: Thanasis: appreciate that ongoing re-modelling discussions can’t happen too frequently.
column63: Rob: in the ontology we could note: although the range is an E1, we expect it to be used with E22s (and other entities). In theory then, you could use a Set for anything: Places with Types (which makes no sense whatsoever); but in practice people won’t do this. So don’t prohibit weirdness.
column64: Joe: grouping collection things arbitrarily, especially in relation to things which aren’t art objects, in CRM… a collection of use cases put forward as part of the Linked Art 3 project proposal. Modelling the collection may require modelling of other things: the people in this meeting only came from such-and-such specialty.
column65: Rob: only a limited number of concepts in scope: these are the other API endpoints. Any of these (with the possible exception of Places?) seem like they could usefully be in a Set of entities. Restricting a composition of Places and Digital Objects seems unhelpful.
column66: Joe: conceptual things?
column67: Rob: it has to be a Textual thing.
column68: Joe: how about the Set of terms which we should not use to describe our objects because they are objectionable?
column69: Joe: subject matter and keywords are notions people will want to use.
column70: Rob: seems like a meta-issue. It’s not describing the objects but the metadata about the objections.
column71: Joe: a set of types: all of these paintings relate to trees; these to water. Fire, Water, Earth relate to the elements. Keywords are often the links software needs to use to connect things.
column72: Rob: in favour of moving forwards with this. There are good use cases for collecting a mix of concepts together in Sets. Would anyone be disappointed if we permitted any Linked Art primary entities being part of a Set?
column73: Joe: the limitation of CIDOC was that you couldn’t combine sets of things.
column74: Rob: CRM doesn’t support our primary use-case of physical and non-physical things.
column75: Thanasis: we need to recognise that a property that connects anything to anything else is not particularly useful for anything deep. But it does cover our use cases very well..
column76: Joe: possible that people will shortcut proper semantics by using Set.
column77: Rob: so we shouldn’t use this as a stand-in for a real relationship.
column78: Joe: examples will help, showing both Set use and nicely-semantically-describe relations.
column79: Thanasis: don’t want it to be a workaround for complex modelling that you want people to do.
column80: Kevin: some of these slightly arbitrary Sets are tending towards being out-of-scope, even though the use-cases are well founded.
column81: George: where does this fit into CIDOC-CRM? If it is more or less like a list, ontologically, -- ah it’s a PropositionalObject -- that’s fine, we just need a nice scope note for this. We need to be clear that you wouldn’t use it for a group of people (they have Group).
column82: #357: cause of death
column83: Rob: people can die, and that’s part of the Person record; but the cause of death is an Event.
column84: Joe: is this only people and not other things? A Group or Organisation could die. Maybe a stretch of the definition but the process is the same. Would this follow this semantic pattern?
column85: Rob: same relationship applied to the dissolution of the group, or the destruction of the whatever.
column86: ?: death of a racehorse? (not getting notified of who is speaking)
column87: Rob: CRM is not good at animals. We have tended to stay away from describing living creatures who are not people.
column88: Joe: Titian’s Death of Action (sp.)? Represents event in the painting.
column89: Thanasis: we do have BiologicalObject in the CRM.
column90: Rob: we can declare the cause of the destruction of objects; but we cannot give the cause of death of a person. Death() currently only has time and place.
column91: Joe: it’s quite common for people to want to describe what materials killed artists: lead poisoning, mercury poisoning, etc. Also see death of Robert Hayden.
column92: Joe: can the Death occur during an event?
column93: Rob: following the destruction pattern - it was caused by another event. The death did not occur during the stabbing, but the stabbing caused the person to die.
column94: Rob: relatively easy to add cause property with range of another Event entity. The cost isn’t high, but if it’s not going to be useful then we shouldn’t do it.
column95: Joe: unlikely for people to want to model old age as a cause of death.
column96: Edward: relationship is just caused not caused death by?
column97: Rob: Yes
column98: Joe: this pattern could be used for many other things.
column99: Rob: yes, we use it for the Production of objects too. The Production was caused by commission. Current property is `O13`. I don’t think the cognitive cost for following this pattern is very high; there’s no added cost for understanding. There is a low cost for API and model documentation. Although we don’t have data in big collection management systems, it does seem worth the minimum cost of implementation.
column100: Thanasis: the `caused_by` property looks to be using CRMsci. I think that triggered by applies to events which do not have agency. We should double check if we are using this for events with agency.
column101: Joe: would this mean that a house being burned down because some lava flowed into it - would be compatible with the model; but someone pouring petrol on it and setting alight - would not.
column102: Rob: if it works for events then it should work for activities. It doesn’t say only for use with E5s and not E7s.
column103: Thanasis: there was discussion of this in relation to causality. Causality is hard to prove so we opted to make it more general.
column104: Joe: we could preface all of the properties with is currently believed to…
column105: Thanasis: intent. Re: chaos theory. There was no intent on the actor’s behalf to cause something; nevertheless, it did happen. The intent was lacking.
column106: Joe: modelling intent then may need additional commentary.
column107: #355: cultural sensitivity fields
column108: Richard: added this to discussion as aware. The very labelling of the topic itself may be a discussion being had also.
column109: Richard: in light of current events and awarenesses, we are going to be re-cataloguing and marking cultural sensitivity: what and why. At first this may be text, but linked from the issue is a vocabulary for making statements of this kind..
column110: Richard: also data relating to who would have been able to see/interact with an object.
column111: ?: At the McCord (sp?) there are objects which need to be covered at night; can only be shown during certain seasons. There is information for this in the acquisition records but not in the ontology.
column112: Rob: there should be a set of controlled values?
column113: Richard: ideally yes, although we may begin with a textual statement.
column114: Richard: Kevin, maybe say something towards this being rolled into a future project strand?
column115: Joe: Tate looking at extending project funding for implementing further vocabulary detoxing.
column116: ?: what about using PROV (from W3C) to record that things were stated at a certain time; rather than continually revisiting the data and bringing into line with current culture.
column117: Joe: the ability to capture mixed or conflicting beliefs would be wonderful. But if there are objects which have restrictions on use, how can we make this data searchable/usable/findable to a user and not just a historian of the data.
column118: Kevin: we have proposed to AHRC to look at how institutions are approaching this work and examine what is recorded in the data. There’s potentially interesting work here: to try and understand how this maps into institutional mission and whether the data can support it. Then how this is modelled, etc., is complicated.
column119: Rob: we have shied away from modelling how people’s beliefs have changed over time. No one has the data and it becomes very complicated very quickly.
column120: George: re implementation suggestion comment in issue: P2 is not right; maybe Name Use? This thing was categorised by this curator at this time and it had this now not-kocher-to-use term. Similarly: this other group doesn’t classify things as the curators do, but they consider that it has this other meaning.

Need to check back to make sure people are happy their data is used for O’Keeffe model. Sami will reach to get continued approval and/or new data. Second objective of these calls is to try out new technologies like a shared whiteboard over Zoom.

Try to have two parts: presentation of LA as it is and break out of focused modelling over Zoom. Hope to do first round late in July and then in September.

Kevin: happy to include any topic but will need co-investigator who has that as speciality. Ideal strand would be for that knowledge to intersect with an institution interested in developing LA as a technology. Richard: provenance would be doable? There are established people. Kevin: really interested in exploring that, ask your colleagues. Need to talk about provenance of a period or particular material type. Dave: Distribution of collection as to ethnicity. This may ramp up into an actual level of access and this could join LA. Joe: that will likely be the same in other institutions (similar to paintings by women at National Gallery, cannot search now). Kevin: if timing works over the next couple of months, this could be a good focus.
column58: Jamie: clarifying about provenance, W3C standard for each claim? Kevin: referring to ownership of work of art. Joe: Provenance = Soap opera of art history.
column59: Kevin: Looking for an individual who comes to mind in an institution who has interest and speciality. Also could be an institutional directive. Joe: What about Getty Provenance project? Rob: left the Getty, and a lot of data cleaning in the background. Joe: what about a curator for subject expertise?
column60: Model issues:
column61: Professional Activity vs Professionhttps://github.com/linked-art/linked.art/issues/351Proposal - Add a metatype to specific professional activities, and keep professional activity as well (c.f. artwork / type of work)
column62: Rob: Should we do same sort of pattern as artwork and type of object. Two types done professionally and what type. Would give all possibilities. Eg Profession architect; architecting without being professional, or profession without knowing what type.
column63: Joe: Would this logic be enough to classify someone as an artist, painter, architect etc.?
column64: Rob: should be enough.
column65: Joe: Clear understanding as how to query this would be helpful.
column66: Rob: Lewis Carroll example, artist/author (among lots of others) this pattern allows for all activities, professional or not.
column67: Joe: How to get to “Lewis Carroll” from this in LA.
column68: Rob: {
column69: "type": "Person",
column70: "performed": {
column71: "type": "Activity",
column72: "classified_as": [
column73: {"id": "aat:300393177", "type": "Type", "_label": "Professional Activities"},
column74: {"id": "aat:300024987", "type": "Type", "_label": "Architecting", "classified_as": {"id": "aat:type-of-activity", "type": "Type", "_label": "Type of Activity"}}
column77: Philippe: Can use professional activities twice? Rob: Yes. Philippe: query becomes more complicated. Rob: need to know it is professional and architecting.
column78: Joe: How to get from the event (a larger event with multiple people) to the activity?
column79: Rob: from API point of view, do not have arbitrary activities at top level. Would put the activity under the person.
column80: Rob: this case is to find all the artists and/or all the collectors and they can be one in the same person.
column81: Joe: in the case of exhibition how to connect multiple people? Rob: that could be tricky. Dave: relationship with objects?
column82: Joe: another model test, person with professional paintings and amateur paintings?
column83: Kevin and Joe: question of large project over time with multiple projects. Complex query to find architects involved in creating National Gallery for example. Rob: could be associated with National Gallery as building not as a project. Joe: do not want to encode the same data multiple times.
column84: Bree question of timespan, Rob included in model.
column85: Non specific timespans? First part of century? Rob: all to the second but with fuzziness. Ontology does give flexibility with uncertain timespans. Also can say abstract period of time “Bronze Age” and activity took place in that period without saying when that abstract period is. As long as people know when the abstract period took place.
column86: Rob: Will write up into the person model for double checking. Can cover use cases without stretching anything.
column87: Identifier context https://github.com/linked-art/linked.art/issues/347
column88: Rob: Objects move around and get identified in different ways by different people.
column89: Accession number example. 1997 acc number but there is a pre-1997 number. Need to know earlier museum or would have two identical acc numbers in model.
column90: Joe: Identifier assigned by legal entity. Can this be a third party identifier? Rob: Could be a good case.
column91: Rob: solution is “assigned by”. Based on the id of the museum or other assigner. Lugt number would also fit in here.
column92: Joe: Multiple acc numbers from one institution? National Gallery exhibition gets x number. Sample gets r number. Long term loan gets L number. Purchased gets NG number. An object could have all those numbers depending on history.
column93: : Metatype of Accession Number? Rob: May not solve Joe’s question.
column94: Rob: Is “general_purpose” enough? Does it give the intent of accession number?
column95: Dave: May be more appropriate to record exhibition numbers with exh, not object. Rob: Doesn’t solve long-term loan,
column96: For artist numbers that is solved on the group level. Question is about multiple numbers from one institution.
column97: Joe: Makes query harder. Could look for all accession numbers an filter. Dave: History of accession numbers. Rob: History is easier can put a timespan on it. Not for valid but rather for when it was assigned.
column98: Joe: Case of acc number and Group number. Group numbers also NG numbers.
column99: Rob: Is group different physical thing with its own numbers?
column100: Rob: Basic scenario of who assignes acc number this model is good. We did add other features without problems in model. Can we move forward on this?
column101: Edward’s question about publication. Rob yes: “is_referred_to-by”
column102: Kevin: Purchase case, is that similar to groups? Sub-division of lots? Maybe use this pattern? Joe’s examples may need to be revisited. The shared acc numbers may not have to be part of LA 1.0, if not very common.
column103: Rob: Will put out agenda earlier.

column67: Model issues
column69: Inscriptions and signations.
column70: There is a distinction between a statement about an inscription signature or the inscription/signature itself.
column71: Rob: we have statements already, but we don’t have documentation explaining how to model the actual signature. There are two approaches:
column72: Have the VisualItem of the work represent the LinguisticObject which is the actual inscription
column73: Have the inscription being carried_by the object itself
column74: The trade-off is that we can make comments (in #1) about the qualities of the inscription (it’s blue, or tilted); where as (#2) gives fewer affordances.
column75: Michiel: is the carries property already used for artwork-type patterns or only books?
column76: Rob: not in any of the documentation. So far only for book-like things. I could imagine that a sculpture with a carved inscription or a painting with significant text within the painting, or the words on a building -- all of these things would be text carried by an object. Therefore it’s not going to be uncommon. Although… will museum contributors have the appropriate data in their CMS?
column77: Michiel: what exactly is a VisualItem? Can the VisualItem also carry?
column78: Rob: carries is for the relationship between a physical thing and a textual thing. Whereas represents is more -- what is represented in the visual content. Represents is right here.
column79: Michiel: so a LinguisticObject can be in the range of represents?
column80: Rob: yes. Even non-physical things.
column81: Joe: if you want to document detail about signature then there are likely issues with simply recording a piece of text. Complexity: multiple signatures, obscured, incomplete, removed, etc. From a conservation point of view, there’s difficulty with it simply being text and a number.
column82: Rob: VisualItem would be beneficial here as the text might be Vinc and the -ent was lost.
column83: Joe: the signature is also a physical thing. It’s made of something.
column84: Rob: yes, the materials of the paint of the signature would require a physical HMO to represent the signature.
column85: Michiel: if there is a person depicted. You might want to say it’s been done with thick paint. Maybe this is going too far?
column86: Joe: there’s a difference between a depiction of a person (they are not in the painting) but the signature is there.
column87: Rob: Emmanuelle also commented on a date being present. Either of the suggested patterns work for these circumstances.
column88: Joe: when a photograph has been taken of the signature, where does it hang?
column89: George: depicts more appropriate than carries for visual but needs to be balanced between pragmatic use of data. Creating VisualItem blank nodes for the sake of good modelling might actually lead to confusion if you never have any claims to make about it. Sometimes this might be better tagged as the aspect of the object.
column90: Rob: we have tried to avoid shortcuts wherever possible. Given that there are lots of use cases for the visual work part, I would personally prefer not to introduce a shortcut on this.
column91: George: if normally you’d pass this sort of information through the VisualItem, then using P128_carries would be inconsistent.
column92: Emmanuelle: it’s not unusual for new inscriptions to be acquired/discovered, and it’s important to capture them. We might describe the date when an inscription was made based on its materials.
column93: Michiel: labels of auction house, transporters, and so on. These can be affixed to the rear of a painting. Is VisualItem inappropriate for handling all the positional information in this context?
column94: For example:
column95: inscription: “painted in red ink”, position: left bottom side. Inscription has creator. As well as the content of the inscription.
column96: Watermark: type, creator [empty], description: a shield with a crown holding a scimitar (etc. Latin etc.)
column97: Rob: let’s take positioning first. We have found, in conservation, where somethings is/happened is significant. George and Rob have used a polygon, which gets applied to an image which overlays the position of the inscription. We could have the VisualItem represent the inscription and then it could have position.
column98: Michiel: this would add another object: artwork has physical part which has VisualItem.
column99: Rob: physical part is made of blue paint; the VisualItem part has position and description and it represents “Vincent” as text.
column100: Michiel: the parts could then also have materials?
column101: Rob: yes, this could all go on to the physical part.
column102: Joe: relative physical dimensions?
column103: Rob: we need Thanasis.
column104: Joe: how would you define a panel in an altarpiece? It’s a painting within a sculpture.
column105: Rob: yes, and then recursive parts: the left panel has whatever characteristics…
column106: Michiel: couldn’t the physical part then just carry this inscription and we do away with the VisualItem?
column107: Rob: visual works have some notion of space and layout but text doesn’t. So you need it for positioning. The altarpiece example is a good one. But describing the nested complexities of it in realtime was too much for the notetaker.
column108: Michel: have asked to share examples from the Van Gogh Museum. Will post on GitHub when permitted.
column109: Rob: will also do Irises.

column55: Linked Art II (AHRC funded project) revised plans:
column56: The open community call timetable will be adapted to include virtual engagement workshops:
column57: Early-June: Open Community Call launched (target: 10/06/2020); registration for outreach workshops opened.
column58: Early-July: Panel sift & selection of focus exemplars.
column59: Late-July: virtual outreach workshop(s), including focus exemplars.
column60: Focus exemplars are unlikely to be suitable for final modelling at this stage, but rather we should look to help submitters characterise their needs and assess the fit with Linked Art.
column61: Modelling discussion will be on the selected focus exemplars, but attendance will be open to all interested parties. I.e. we should aim to inform participants in the session, even if it’s not their exemplar.
column62: (Late-July: The DH2020 panel may still go ahead virtually - we await news from the conference organisers)

column81: No official proposal yet, however, there are probably two issues to discuss:
column82: How do we present different models e.g.: in linked art there is one way to describe dimensions. In LCD there will be a more elaborate way… when someone is approaching the api, how do we direct the request to the correct model? Perhaps technically trivial question (or not) but needs to be answered
column83: What to do when one model updates, how do we organize dependency on the other model? We are talking about LCD but there would be other projects as well
column84: Need an intercommunity model for managing the updates… also the question of linked pasts is another example
column85: Question one is easier to try to tackle first
column86: Should we invite someone from related community to describe their work in the call one in three meetings or so?
column87: Thanasis: I was thinking that this should probably be more of a mechanical problem.  Is this realistic? This can be something to discuss in LCD meeting.
column88: Kevin: do we separate between models and apis? Clean part of the separation of what is expected from the resource. There could be a clean separation when you identify the principle of when there would be a more specialized model/partition from the main data
column89: Having a clear view on the conceptual model is ‘relatively’ easy. But the transition to implementation in an api is about agreeing principles of practice.
column90: Dimensions example: should attribute assignment of measurement should be its own api endpoint or should it just be added into the object representation as it is currently in the documentation
column91: How to know from which endpoint you get the more information? E.g. between a Linked Art dimension pattern which just has a little bit of dimension data and the LCD dimension point which would have a rich amount of information.
column92: Need  to see it by use cases
column93: Thanasis: in the long term, if other projects come on board, what level of engagement would one expect with linked art before such a discussion/relation can happen
column94: Rob: if they want to engage, then some in the community that wants to interact should have read the linked art’s documentation
column95: Further on down the road, when linked art documentation is more mature, can help people along more…
column96: Richard: Linked Place framework… the work is fairly independent. Richard follows linked art to see where compatibility may come into place. The use of CRM is what is common between the projects…
column97: Joe Padfield: there’s money to hire in SSHOC, to create heritage science fair data sets… they will be created with CIDOC CRM. Would be of interest to see how this overlaps with Linked.art (https://www.sshopencloud.eu/)
column98: How does one build a test model. It would be useful to have examples of how you build your own dataset using linked art

column100: Emmanuelle: haven’t heard of this work. There is movement ahead on the LIDO project under a new grant. Could be useful to make sure to march in the same direction.
column101: Joe: AHRC Discovery projects… lots of funding here.  (https://ahrc.ukri.org/research/fundedthemesandprogrammes/tanc-opening-uk-heritage-to-the-world/)

column103: Relevant Outcomes: interested in organizing shared workshops/webinar (in relation with Keven's project, among others), have linked art data model checked against the requirement of the workshop participants. They are also creating material for explaining linked open data for researchers/beginners.
column104: Issue 219: Representative objects
column105: Have representative objects for an artist or style or place
column106: Joe: could also extend this thought to representative object of spaces
column107: Rob proposal: we should have a type to link between the two objects. Can use the pattern of the relationship modelling already in linked art.
column108: Thanasis: there is no substantial relationship between the two objects. This is a type of categorization relevant to a context.
column109: Joe: do you care about context? The thing is exemplary relevant to some context.
column110: George: Could use attribute assignment. Seems like a common practice so we should be able to capture it. If you have a relationship and add a property on top, people will use that for everything. Context is very interesting, such as for an exhibition.  Going through an Attribute Assignment lets you contextualize using existing machinery in the model. Basic structure would be to use assigned / assigned_to, with AA node in the middle. Still wouldn't have a property for X being exemplary for Y -- this can be the type, exemplary-ness.  Then have actors and time and so on.
column111: Joe: if we have the notion of assigning a set of things to the object as being exemplary… then should we consider order?
column112: Rob: we try to avoid rdf:list. In json you can rely on the order which is not great but functional.
column113: Also consider this issue in the CRM SIG: http://www.cidoc-crm.org/Issue/ID-407-ordinal-property-for-e55-type
column114: The question or order actually lurks in the future.
column115: Joe: use case… institutions top 100 objects… national gallery has done this many times. This would need context.
column116: Kevin: What is relation between highlights and exhibitions? Is there an overlap there?
column117: Should back to the relation of this to exhibitions in another context
column118: Concerns/Decision: rob will document the attribute assignment pattern and see if it works and bring it back to the group.

In short consent is required for recording meetings. Rob has reported that recording meetings is not appropriate as far as the Getty is concerned (also see next section for further discussion)
column59: Not taking practice: People in general happy with names to be mentioned in the minutes of the meetings.
column60: Using GitHub: People in general feeling happy to use Github.

column62: DB: Does the issue about recording apply to publicly available records, or can it be done through private channels.
column63: RS: The recording without consent is not possible regardless publication.
column64: DB: Would a different zoom account get over this limitation.
column65: RS: In theory a different zoom account is not limited by Getty regulations.
column66: AV: would a mini consent form work at the beginning?
column67: RS: No the limitation applies to even meeting with consent. A different account may be easier to resolve the issue. Call for another organisation with a zoom account. Is the recording valuable?
column68: JP: Are there analytics on use?
column69: RS: Consulting YouTube analytics: A few views reported on some calls. Enough to make it useful material.
column70: Feedback from textual boxes of the form:
column71: Summarized points from textual feedback form:
column72: Timing: Wish we had more frequent meetings
column73: Timing: Difficult to assess issues during a meeting, and don’t all have the time between meetings to review regularly - more warning for agendas would help.
column74: Timing/Process: Consensus on last meeting issues, then discuss this meeting’s issues, and identify next meeting’s issues. Then have the two weeks to think about them.
column75: Skills: No one has all the skills needed to participate in every aspect, but it’s the combination of skills from everyone that will make it work
column76: Skills: Feel less able to participate in modeling discussions
column77: Process: Issue raiser can chair the part of the meeting for that issue
column78: JP: Can we document the issue resolution process on GitHub and then report back to the meeting the following round. I.e. include a summary of previous work on the issue and proceed discussing questions on it following from that. Theoretically one issue will feed to another, i.e. make a chain of issues (not sure I am capturing this correctly).
column79: Agreed: Agreeing processes to allow issues or discussions that are raised during the summary are then added to the list for future meetings - makes it easier to end new discussions and stick to a planned agenda, while still letting people's ideas be discussed overall.
column80: RS: Power of the group is in shared skills. Got to come up with a method to make setting the agenda more transparent. Commenting on issues is an indication of people being interested in them. This could be a way to set the agenda, i.e. start with issues with comments and if none is commented then move on to other. Interaction with the issue in the form of “thumbs-up” clicks is enough.
column81: Agreed: To prioritise the commented issues for the agenda.
column82: RS: Good idea for issue raiser to chair the part of the meeting that discusses the issue.
column83: AV: Same practice in CRM-SIG and it works
column84: JP: Also useful to ensure that the raiser has understood the resolution. Also an issue assignment method would be useful.
column85: RS: People should have access to “assign” tools if they have a GitHub account. If they are not included in the LA repo, then Rob can add them.
column86: Agreed: That the issue raiser can chair the bit of the meeting related to the issue.
column87: RS: The questionnaire is useful to ensure that everyone gets the chance to contribute.
column88: JP: Consider a separate call only on modelling with worked examples to share experience with other people. This is to address the concerns about lack of time given that the regular meetings are only an hour. A bit of modelling surgery setup
column89: Edward: A tag/label may be useful for an issue, so that an issue itself can be about a specific example of modeling a set of data.
column90: Agreed: new tag on GitHub “mapping” for issues about specific datasets
column91: I have mentioned this before, but I have been working on a system to visualise mapping examples: https://jpadfield.github.io/cidoc-crm.examples/ In the example it is cidoc stuff but it could be used - simple text automatically converted into interactive web models. (JP) Might even just be nice to share agreed example models, if not for discussion.
column92: Kevin: London we put an open call out for people attending the workshop, beyond the people on the calls, to bring their favorite example and a difficult one.  Then this group helped in breakout groups to try and see how linked art fitted modeling the data. Worked well, but a step away from more validation task of working with real data from systems. The timely point of the AHRC grant will have a call for the wider community to suggest use cases with the aim to work up to detailed exemplars. One question is how to continue that in lockdown, as original plan was for a face to face. Not sure we can directly bring them together but thinking how to do it would be useful. Different to brainstorming around a table.
column93: Thanasis: Asked consortium to submit examples of documentation. We curated them in advance to make sure they were useful examples. Purpose was also didactic for the participants. Divided into groups according to interests and people with more experience with CRM would explain the mapping. Some people were even convinced of the process :)  For LCD we consider changes too, haven’t worked out how to do it. Kristen has suggested a format of online seminars / tutorials where people bring their data and we spend an hour looking at the data online. But haven’t formalized that yet.  We can report back when there’s more discussions.
column94: George: Great if those were recorded, especially if they solve a problem. Towards a wider issue putting something together in a PhD program in Cyprus to pick up CRM. Informal dial-in radio show for semantics. Dear abby… :D [/rs]
column95: GB: Having visual and audio with real data and being able to follow is much more useful.
column96: RS: Would this need to be a separate call or replace current regular calls? Possibly be a separate call as the membership may be different. At the moment two calls are not enough to cover all activity.
column97: Kevin:  Mapping discussion where Richard  (e.g.) has data and how to map.  And then the more engaging activity to get others from outside of the group.  E.g. curation of exemplars. Two different cases (or steps to get stuck in)
column98: RS: We could usgmae the same process for the discussion but separate workflow to enter the discussion. Individual members may discuss with internal people who wish to discuss modelling and bring them in to the more topical mapping call.
column99: KP: People in the group can discuss and deliver mappings advice to external anyway.
column100: KW: Consider how we could keep track of specific examples to refer to in the future.
column101: RS: Showing example of the photoarchive on the linked.art website as an example of a sample record.
column102: JP: The specific example may be a little scary for people. Joe’s example showing visualization of triples to be shown with a direct HTML links. There is also a way to include documentation on these model-nodes. Joe built is for a specific example but we can replace the underlying data with different examples.
column103: RS: Try to find time and example to do a more practical and model oriented call.
column104: Agreed: Richard to bring data for example, Edward,  Karina to flesh out use cases. Rob to circulate a doodle poll.

column49: Kevin [via Rob]: working on re-configuring the AHRC grant to try to figure out how to manage the logistics of hiring and starting.

column52: Model issues
column53: Issue 237 (see also 107)
column54: Rob: proposal pending since September would be to use a simple class for relationships with some from/to attributes. However, Attribute Assignment may be a nicer way of doing this. Both patterns are very, very similar; so if we could use generic AAs then we wouldn’t have to make a relationship class. Meaning one less thing to maintain.
column55: In relation to the model example for student-teacher-school. Attribute Assignement, used here:
column56: ```turtle
column57: <teacher> assigned_to_by AttribAssignment
column58: AttribAssignment assigns <student> ;
column59: P177_assigned_property_type <teacher-of> .
column61: George: doing something like the AA pattern in order to express arbitrary things (x is related to y) as random relationship... this seems like a better pattern. But I wouldn’t make it recommended. Plus one to current suggestion.
column62: Joe: would you want to twin this with a vocabulary of relationships? For Linked.Art, do we centralise an agreed list of types?
column63: Antoine: there’s always a need to find a pertinent vocabulary, which is a wider problem than the specific implementation being discussed.
column64: Rob: how to express sufficient usability balanced with sufficient interoperability? The vocabulary and the pattern are inextricably linked.
column65: Thanasis: not particularly happy with the structure. The Attribute Assignment is often used to indicate that somebody has an opinion about something. In a way, I do not see the student as an attribute that the teacher receives. In some cases we may want to express this, but in others it exists already - in which case expressing an AA doesn’t make sense.
column66: Rob: because AA is typically expressing properties not relationships?
column67: Thanasis: for example, if somebody is a sibling of someone else… ontologically they are [related] and not properties.
column68: George: yes; which is why if you have any other option then don’t do this. One of the reasons we didn’t want to handle social relations is to avoid biting off more than we can chew in terms of the ontology.
column69: Thanasis: is the problem that the CRM soc haven’t formalised the relationship properties? It’s a matter of time before Linked Art accepts their resolution. We don’t want to make a decision here beforehand.
column70: Joe: as an alternative, one of the ways this could be done is make the person a member of a group. Then define the relationships in the definition of the group. Also not perfect.
column71: Rob: Getty has done this too. It works OK for people and roles. E.g. the PM of New Zealand is a Group which only ever has one member. But issues arise when we’re not talking about a person or set of people. And directionality is tricky too. Which essentially just moves the problem. Having something consistent with representative objects would be good as it would be consistent. So we want a relatively-straightforward-and-not-wrong way to express this.
column72: Rob:
column73: ```turtle
column74: Conceptual Object assigned_to_by AttribAssign
column75: Assign assigns Type ( number )
column77: Does this seem semantically incorrect? Compare this purely mathematical example to the specific sibling example?
column78: George: if you knew the direct relationship then you would use an existing component of the ontology. This has to support cases where it’s not known.
column79: Thanasis: how soon does this need to be implemented? Would it be better to sort this is CRM SOC beforehand?
column80: Joe: you could have relationships between two E1s. That’s the level of the generic problem.
column81: Thanasis: I don’t think so; I think it’s within the bounds of social interaction.
column82: George: hasn’t the problem opened up more broadly? Student-teacher is just an example. But also… the moon is related to the sun… through galaxy… things.
column83: Rob: where we have these statements we want to use them.
column84: Joe: any use of this data must have strict processing rules so that properties aren’t creeping into inferences for other relations.
column85: Thanasis: if we want to express a relationship between any two things, how valuable is allowing searching on it? Maybe we do not support such a thing with tooling.
column86: Rob: yes, search could become terribly complicated or unreliable.
column87: Joe: this type of relationship is important to hold on to, but how should it be re-used. There’s a difference between data being held in limbo pending being modelled and it remaining so for use.
column88: Rob: regardless of all the other problems, the September proposal seems worse than Attribute Assignment. However AA has exactly the same set of problems with the exception that it will already be understood by CRM community members. Therefore, let’s work with SOC to explore the bonds issue. Because if there is a better pattern coming from bonds it would be better to avoid having two patterns.
column89: Ryan: bye
column90: Rob: would prefer, however, to have something written down for this pending resolution at the end of the calendar year. This at least improves the situation.
column91: Thanasis: it might be unclear, in this model, what is assigned to what. How do you decide which side the thing goes? Do we really have such a burning need for this? In terms of peoples’ real data do we need this in v1?
column92: Rob: good question. We could be silent on it. Probably every CMS has examples of HMOs with related_object, which is similar. Both related- and representative-objects seem pretty ubiquitous. So would prefer to have something in v1, yes.
column93: Thanasis: OK
column94: Antoine: agree. It matches better the DCAT qualified relationship pattern. Still a bit luke warm about Attribute Assignment as it may encourage people to put provenance data here. But if that provenance is optional it's fine!
column95: Joe: we need several worked examples to ensure that the directionality works. You may always require pairs of AAs, because both things have a relationship. This is messy but captures the duality.
column96: Antoine: the other pattern supported from and to.
column97: Issue 219
column98: (Dimensions of arrangement)
column99: Rob: Getty CMS has dimension with types which simply describe those dimensions at the time that the dimensions were taken. State does complicate things significantly in that it is an ongoing thing in an ontology that is configured around changes in state.
column100: Rob: is there something we want to try to work on, or defer? Do we want to tackle this?
column101: Joe: is this a class question or a type question? Class would complicate the ontology, with an infinite number of instances of the state of the object. Making vocabulary controlled hierarchies of types is maybe a simple solution.
column102: Object has dimension. Dimension has type width. Width has type width with lid open.
column103: It’s a bunch of types either way you do it! At scale it might be a lot simpler to string together a lot of different dimensions than model all the events which invoke state changes in the object.
column104: Rob: what about a polyhierarchy of the terminology: dimension terms and state terms?
column105: George: use technique and procedure and say that measuring in one state or another is not a function of the object. Rather that we used to open-map style of measuring. Object went through a measurement event. We would need a sensible vocabulary to describe these measuring procedures. There are real discussions about this, so presumably we can name and describe these.

column57: API issues first
column58: #166 Blank Nodes
column59: Rob: Answer from Philadelphia was could use blank node whenever needed except when API requires it to be a top level resource in JSON-LD.
column60: Thanasis: Apart from dereferencing any other problems?
column61: Rob: Eg if a third party wanted to annotate the blank node rather than system as a whole. Could annotate the person, but could not annotate the name specifically. That is clumsy because we do have the machinery to do this.
column62: Thanasis: Not encouraging. Just saying if there is not a URI then do not worry.
column63: Rob: But if one can then one should use the URI.
column64: Dave: Annotation could record the use of the API and not identifier? Similar to image identifying. Image of an object on a website. Gives a reference to an image without an ID (concept not an ID). But there are instances of creation of content where one has to refer to a particular image in time. Are there parallels?
column65: Rob: In Web Annotation Model there are cases. The source is a diskimage and selects a byte range. In Xpath Selects a span. No well known standard in graphs. JSON path could work for representation. Does rely on annotation specific machinery, but does solve for this specific use case.
column66: Dave: If modelled everything as annotations then could solve.
column67: Rob: To repeat, may use blank nodes but should use URI’s. Must use URI’s if it is dereferenced according to API.
column68: Dave: Clarify when one should make up a URI? Eg if there is a practice for creating a URI then one should create it, but do not just make one up out of thin air.
column69: Jamie: Why does one want to use a blank node?
column70: Rob: If there is not a stable ID in content management system. Then it means artificially creating one that is reproducible across changing content management systems. Question from Ethan arose out of not wanting to store all the created URI’s.
column71: Thanasis: In CRM to get from one entity to another may have to jump through a number of extra entities. So one would have create extra nodes.
column72: Rob: Guidance for this - should it be an implementation note?
column73: Dave: Error on the side of implementation note.
column74: #202 Allow language based content negotiation.
column75: Rob: French/English example. Only wanting French but take English if no French.
column76: Rob: Should not prevent, but no reason to call it out. Antoine says could note the possibility not do not recommend a best practice.
column77: Dave: Concern about the size of response? A lot of not typically used languages may discard the results. May get header sent without user realizing it, need to be cognizant if wants all languages. Can there be a wildcard on except language?
column78: Rob: Implicit “everything else” default.
column79: Dave: THis may exclude all except one example (ie only US-English in a US search, would exclude other languages that the user may have wanted).
column80: Bree: Different resources in countries with two or more languages and parts of the population only speak one (Finland example). Gives different results based.
column81: Rob: Problematic when one does not return results in another language. Another problem if browser cannot swap languages.
column82: Jamie: Not done in server. Example where a user does not get anything should not be the case.
column83: Rob: Troublesome case is when one asks for something and it is not available, does one get nothing or something else?
column84: Dave: Concern about not saying “do not do this” is one would miss out on substantial portion of graph because of excluding languages. However, could be a useful API feature. Could be misleading if one does not realize this at the beginning of implementation.
column85: Rob: In the absence of select language header then it should return all data it has access to.
column86: Dave: Could be confusing. Need to say in spec “ignore language header”. Casual user will only see language set in browser. Is that a problem?
column87: Rob: Does seem like a problem. It is data to be rendered. Normal user actively browsing JSON-LD is low. Downside is size. Ignore except language would return same data in multiple languages.
column88: Dave: May have to create another standard in order to reduce number of languages in the response. URL would be different and explicitly filtering on another language in this casae so it is obvious in this case. And not the canonical URI.
column89: Rob: If “except language” is absent (probably the default case) then return all languages and allow client to sort it out. If present then return based on preferences.
column90: So can ask for everything or if one is aware
column91: #205 API versioning approach
column92: Rob: Could use same versioning approach as IIIF.  Major, Minor, Patch system.
column93: Dave: That is not efficient. Kiosk scenario from github. Do not want to pay vendor to revise kiosk in every version of Linked Art.
column94: Rob: Requirement for media type.
column95: Dave: Most would be programmatic so could use this header. Caveat is would have to get into habit of setting headers.
column96: Rob: Version 3 of IIIF example. Could specify version from the same URI and would return correct version.
column97: Use semantic versioning and version based content negotiation to manage cross version software incorporation.
column98: Adjourn

So after a travel date face to face (provisionally Amsterdam) is 17-19 June (Wed-Fri). 16 June available for London->Amsterdam travel. CRM sig is the following week.

column55: Kevin: Announced grants on AHRC website. Two workshops London and Edinburgh.
column57: https://github.com/linked-art/linked.art/issues/307
column58: Links to external authorities for people and places.
column59: Skos:exactmatch is semantically incorrect (misappropriated term). Do not want to use owl:sameAs because it associates metadata with entity not just properties of the entity. Owl:sameAs too strong. One option uses probably. Another is to create
column60: Two patterns. Either uri in model or have it refer to local crm. SHould not use both.
column61: Solutions from Rob’s post on github: long attribute assignment, skos:ExactMatch, owl:sameAs, find another term, invent new term.
column62: Antoine: Prefer skos:exactmatch because simpler. What kind of resource do we want in this position on the graph? Do we want Person/Concept distinction in the pattern? If your local authority is made of Concepts like ULAN, can you stick them in the 'creator' slot for the object?
column63: Rob: Pattern to aim for “id” “type” “exact_match” (on github). Local uri of person matches to external. Mapping of ULAN to Linked Art is done but not public. Backing for Open Refine reconciliation.
column64: Linked Art view will be a real person, not a concept of a person.
column65: Antoine: Some authorities will have people as concepts. If we're comfortable with the issue concerning person and concept, i.e. one can use a concept as a person in the 'creator' slot of the pattern, then can use exact_match, because the fundamental issue in the model appears before :-).
column66: Rob: Disregarding local authorities that a person is a concept vastly outweighs having to map the local authority listing person as a concept. Also will not have to map any external authorities in future. At some point we are going to have to deal with this.
column67: Kevin: Is this problem consistent enough to fix it programatically? And does anyone care enough to make it consistent?
column68: Rob: Long form is consistent. A clever system with owl property chains could substitute the long form. Kevin: That seems plausible if there is confidence that is possible.
column69: Rob: Can it be expressed in owl, not sure? And would it avoid the actual problem of exact_match. Kevin: It is a matter of where one wants consistency.
column70: Antoine: Infers existence of a blank node. May be possible by defining specific classes (class of things with attribution that is wanted)
column71: Rob: Will discuss with Vlad.
column72: Rob: Any concerns with using exact_match and exploring an automated role to set up long form pattern? Or other suggestions? Or anyone not ok with exact_match?
column74: Rob: We use vocabs in LA for proxy for classes. In others (Bibframe etc) there are specific classes (Painting, Book, etc). We have to be carefull which vocab entries we require/recommend/allow.. We cannot enforce a vocabulary, but it could break a LA processor. Reduces interoperability but not catastrophic.
column75: Spreadsheet put together to break down recommendations/required terms.
column76: Required Terms:
column77: Metatypes - “type of object” etc. If not understand cannot use
column78: Replacement for Ontology
column79: Trivally enumerable sets
column80: API distinguishing terms
column81: Recommended Terms:
column82: Enumerable sets - e.g. parts of Personal Names - “first name”
column83: Ultra-Common Terms - Provide list of recommended terms.
column84: Listed
column85: Other - Frequent terms but not as common as above
column86: Agreed to try and develop as it is applied
column87: Example in Spreadsheet for parts - some recommended and some optional.

column55: Went through issues that are closable, caught up on issues that came up in the last few months around provenance, and started on more general topics. Exhibition modeling was tackled on the second day (major topic of this f2f meeting), based on many use cases from MoMA. Activity of putting on the exhibition, concept of the exhibition (important bc activities dont have subjects), planning documents (checklists…). Two other levels considered: Series/program of exhibitions (higher level) and traveling exhibitions (lower level). Third day: API and concrete implementation details (URIs and their reuse).

column68: Modeling:
column69: How to deal with the Language of _labelhttps://github.com/linked-art/linked.art/issues/319
column70: The purpose of the label is to have a very easy way to add documentation to the data (and small cost to the publisher). What if the person looking at the language of the label does not speak that language? They would still need to dereference the URI.
column71: The question is do we want to have multiple labels available? Would anyone use this functionality? Rob thinks it might be overkill and that we should have a rule about not having multiple labels. Dave B agrees. Sami: no use case at Newfields for multiple labels.
column72: “_label” with the underscore is intended to convey that it is not data.
column73: Named but unidentified actorshttps://github.com/linked-art/linked.art/issues/246
column74: How to document how to describe un-identified actors.
column75: Use case: we know that someone called Yan van de velde has created many items but there are 3 creators with the same name. Option 1: Create an unidentified Yan van de velde which returns many undifferentiated results so unsatisfying. Option 2: create a group that represents a set of people but that’s a bit strange from ontology pov bc we could have a group with 1 person.
column76: Suggestion: Create an unidentified group of describable people.
column77: Use case: want to know all works made in the 16th century. Searching for unknown people directly does not make sense, but searching for their properties indirectly works better.
column78: Cases of that in MoMA archives, and PMA collection
column79: What about unidentified French artists and so forth? Yes, we could have a separate group for each distinguishing properties but we want to stay away from creating groups for individuals.
column80: Note: it is not required that all the members of a group must have participated in the creation of the object.
column81: Anonymous group use case (Kevin).

column87: Principle: don’t focus on the creation aspect but on how to retrieve the data. Use the w3c LDP  standard https://www.w3.org/TR/ldp/ It focuses mostly on create delete and update. We might want to consider the notion of containers from LDP
